attributes.content_markup:
Scribe is pleased to announce its great line up of authors who will be participating in the Melbourne Writers at the Convent weekend, being held at The Abbotsford Convent from Friday 15th to Sunday 17th February.

International Scribe authors inlcude Cullen Murphy (The New Rome?), Catherine O'Flynn (What Was Lost), and Tan Twan Eng (The Gift of Rain). Our local authors include Tony Kevin (Walking the Camino), Carmen Michael (Chasing Bohemia), Ellie Nielsen (Buying a Piece of Paris), Chris Womersley (The Low Road), and Richard Watson (The Future Files).

For program and booking details click here .
attributes.content:
_Scribe is pleased to announce its great line up of authors who will be participating in the Melbourne Writers at the Convent weekend, being held at The Abbotsford Convent from Friday 15th to Sunday 17th February._
_International Scribe authors inlcude Cullen Murphy ([The New Rome?](http://www.scribepublications.com.au/book/thenewrome)), Catherine O'Flynn ([What Was Lost](http://www.scribepublications.com.au/book/whatwaslost)), and Tan Twan Eng ([The Gift of Rain](http://www.scribepublications.com.au/book/thegiftofrain)). Our local authors include Tony Kevin ([Walking the Camino](http://www.scribepublications.com.au/book/walkingthecamino)), Carmen Michael ([Chasing Bohemia](http://www.scribepublications.com.au/book/chasingbohemia)), Ellie Nielsen ([Buying a Piece of Paris](http://www.scribepublications.com.au/book/buyingapieceofparis)), Chris Womersley ([The Low Road](http://www.scribepublications.com.au/book/thelowroad)), and Richard Watson ([The Future Files](http://www.scribepublications.com.au/book/futurefiles))._
For program and booking details [click here](http://www.writersattheconvent.com/) .
attributes.title: Scribe Authors at Writers at the Convent 2008

attributes.content_markup:
The 2008 Perth Writers Festival, running from Thursday 21st to Sunday 24th February, will host several Scribe authors, including five of our international authors.

Authors from Scribe attending are Naomi Wolf (The End of America), Cullen Murphy (The New Rome?), Catherine O'Flynn (What Was Lost), Tan Twan Eng (The Gift of Rain), Stefan Klein (The Science of Happiness) Gideon Haigh (Asbestos House), and Carmen Michael (Chasing Bohemia).

For more program and booking details click here.
attributes.content:
_The 2008 Perth Writers Festival, running from Thursday 21st to Sunday 24th February, will host several Scribe authors, including five of our international authors._

While strategically significant as one of the worldâs most important energy corridors, the politics and alliances within the Middle East are frequently misrepresented and over-hyped by Western media. Three commentators on Middle Eastern affairs â Robert Baer, Peter Rodgers and Samina Yasmeen â share their thoughts on the current political situation and what this means for foreign policy makers. Chair: Miriam Cosic.

http://www.perthfestival.com.au/perthwritersfestival/

Chaired by Deb Anderson.

attributes.content_markup: Stephan Faris has reported from Africa, the Middle East, and China for publications including Time Magazine, Fortune Magazine, The Atlantic Monthly, and Salon.com. He has written about war in Liberia, the rise of Islamists in Somalia, genocide trials in Rwanda, oil in Nigeria, refugees from Darfur, and Internet censorship in China. He also covered the invasion of Iraq for the New York Daily News. He is now based in Rome, where he contributes to Fortune Magazine and travels to Africa and China. Today he talks to Russ Radcliffe.
attributes.content: Stephan Faris has reported from Africa, the Middle East, and China for publications including Time Magazine, Fortune Magazine, The Atlantic Monthly, and Salon.com. He has written about war in Liberia, the rise of Islamists in Somalia, genocide trials in Rwanda, oil in Nigeria, refugees from Darfur, and Internet censorship in China. He also covered the invasion of Iraq for the New York Daily News. He is now based in Rome, where he contributes to Fortune Magazine and travels to Africa and China. Today he talks to Russ Radcliffe.
attributes.title: âForeign Correspondentâ â Writers at the Convent Festival

attributes.content_markup:
Would you put your life on the line for a good story? Stephan Faris, Benjamin Gilmour and Peter Rodgers have spent time in various hotspots around the world, including the Middle East, Pakistan, East Timor and Darfur. They discuss their new books and what draws them to troubled regions. Chair: Josh Wilson.

http://www.perthfestival.com.au/perthwritersfestival/
attributes.content:

Climate change has dominated debate for years but governments have taken no real action. With âclimate change fatigueâ a growing threat, will we see a turning point in the fight against global warming? Stephan Faris, Clive Hamilton and Alan Weisman in discussion with James Woodford look at conservancy, future choices and consequences of inaction.

http://www.perthfestival.com.au/perthwritersfestival/

Branded a terrorist, accused of attending al-Qaeda training camps in Afghanistan and incarcerated and tortured in Pakistan, Egypt, Afghanistan and Guantanamo for three years, Mamdouh Habib was eventually released without charge and reunited with his wife and four children in Australia. He reveals the full story of his journey to hell and back.

http://www.perthfestival.com.au/perthwritersfestival/

attributes.content_markup:
Mamdouh Habib and Najaf Mazari are two Australian citizens whose stories differ from the majority of the population. One was unjustly detained while overseas as part of ‘the war on terror’, while the other fled the Taliban to safety on our shores. They discuss the extraordinary experiences they have endured and how their lives have changed. Chair: Robert Hillman

http://www.perthfestival.com.au/perthwritersfestival/

attributes.content_markup:
Climate change, not great for humans is a disaster for wildlife. Already doing it tough through drought, loss of habitat and road kill, Victoriaâs wildlife face an even more uncertain future due to the bushfires that ravaged Victoria in February.

During the bushfire season, volunteer wildlife carers risk their lives to search still smouldering forests for injured and starving animals. Expenses funded from their own pockets, they need our help and they need it now to continue caring for our native animals and birds.

The Save Our Wildlife Fund is presenting an event âWriters For Wildlifeâ on March 22nd at the Abbotsford Convent. Writers appearing at the event: Robert Gott, a.k.a. Naked Man and the creator of the William Power Series, Robin Bowles, true crime and fiction writer, Kelly Gardiner, childrenâs author and Adrian Hyland, mystery writer and a resident of fire ravaged St Andrews will talk about bushfires, books and life in country Victoria. All proceeds will go to wildlife carers in bushfire disaster areas.

The start time: 1.30 p.m. join the crowd at the Convent and help save our wildlife.

Tickets: $10.00 $8.00 concession, light refreshments included.

Abbotsford Convent, 1 St Heliers St. Melways Ref: 44 G5. Parking Available opposite the Convent.

Enquiries/Donations: 9899 0127 email: sowfund@hotmail.com
attributes.content:
Climate change, not great for humans is a disaster for wildlife. Already doing it tough through drought, loss of habitat and road kill, Victoriaâs wildlife face an even more uncertain future due to the bushfires that ravaged Victoria in February.
During the bushfire season, volunteer wildlife carers risk their lives to search still smouldering forests for injured and starving animals. Expenses funded from their own pockets, they need our help and they need it now to continue caring for our native animals and birds.
The Save Our Wildlife Fund is presenting an event âWriters For Wildlifeâ on March 22nd at the Abbotsford Convent. Writers appearing at the event: Robert Gott, a.k.a. Naked Man and the creator of the William Power Series, Robin Bowles, true crime and fiction writer, Kelly Gardiner, childrenâs author and Adrian Hyland, mystery writer and a resident of fire ravaged St Andrews will talk about bushfires, books and life in country Victoria. All proceeds will go to wildlife carers in bushfire disaster areas.
The start time: 1.30 p.m. join the crowd at the Convent and help save our wildlife.
Tickets: $10.00 $8.00 concession, light refreshments included.
Abbotsford Convent, 1 St Heliers St. Melways Ref: 44 G5. Parking Available opposite the Convent.
Enquiries/Donations: 9899 0127 email: sowfund@hotmail.com
attributes.title: Robert Gott at 'Writers for Wildlife'

attributes.content_markup:
Norman Doidge in Conversation with Caroline Baum
The discovery of neuroplasticity, that our thoughts can change the structure and function of our brains even into old age, is the most important breakthrough in our understanding of the brain in 400 years. Norman Doidge, author of The Brain That Changes Itself, talks to Caroline Baum about the principles we can all use to overcome brain limitations, and explores the profound implications of the changing brain.


Cost: $15/$10


Bookings: 02 9250 1988 or visit www.swf.org.au
attributes.content:
**Norman Doidge in Conversation with Caroline Baum**
The discovery of neuroplasticity, that our thoughts can change the structure and function of our brains even into old age, is the most important breakthrough in our understanding of the brain in 400 years. Norman Doidge, author of _[The Brain That Changes Itself](http://www.scribepublications.com.au/book/thebrainthatchangesitself)_, talks to Caroline Baum about the principles we can all use to overcome brain limitations, and explores the profound implications of the changing brain.

attributes.title: Norman Doidge at Sydney Writers Festival

attributes.content_markup:
The Brain That Changes Itself: Judge for Yourself
The discovery that the human brain can change its own structure and function with thought and experience, turn on its own genes to change its circuitry, reorganise itself and change its operation is the most important alteration in our understanding of the brain in 400 years. Norman Doidge, author of The Brain That Changes Itself, explores how, given that the human brain has been plastic, we have missed this core feature. He will visually illustrate how brain change occurs with dramatic examples of people actually in the process of changing their brains and describe new cures for neurological and psychiatric conditions. The discovery that the brain can change itself also has major implications for everyday life, helping us to understand how education, relationships, love and sexuality shape us. It has major implications for understanding the humanities, social sciences and culture. Cultural practices and experiences actually rewire our brains; that differences between cultures may give rise to different kinds of brains is a radical new idea.


Cost: $15/$10
Bookings: 02 9250 1988 or visit www.swf.org.au
attributes.content:

The discovery that the human brain can change its own structure and function with thought and experience, turn on its own genes to change its circuitry, reorganise itself and change its operation is the most important alteration in our understanding of the brain in 400 years. Norman Doidge, author of _[The Brain That Changes Itself](http://www.scribepublications.com.au/book/thebrainthatchangesitself)_, explores how, given that the human brain has been plastic, we have missed this core feature. He will visually illustrate how brain change occurs with dramatic examples of people actually in the process of changing their brains and describe new cures for neurological and psychiatric conditions. The discovery that the brain can change itself also has major implications for everyday life, helping us to understand how education, relationships, love and sexuality shape us. It has major implications for understanding the humanities, social sciences and culture. Cultural practices and experiences actually rewire our brains; that differences between cultures may give rise to different kinds of brains is a radical new idea.

attributes.content_markup:
Michael Bachelard, author of Behind the Exclusive Brethren, is taking part in three sessions at the Sydney Writers Festival on Friday 22 May:


10.00â11.00 am: The Future of Journalism
Journalism is quickly changing. Reportage and commentary are no longer left to professionals. Instead, âcitizen journalistsâ armed with mobile phone cameras and laptops offer their own views. Should this be celebrated? Or does it raise questions about objectivity? Many welcome the demise of the highly centralised world of journalism, but when anyone can be a news reporter, and professional news reporters seem less than critically minded, how do we know what is true? Stefan Aust, Michael Bachelard and Sally Neighbour discuss with Jeff Sparrow.


1.00â2.00 pm: Losing My Religion
With the rising popularity of writers such as Dawkins and Hitchens, religion and faith have been dominant themes in contemporary non-fiction publishing. Richard Holloway, Michael Bachelard and Tom Frame discuss the challenges of writing objectively about a subject like religious belief when objectivity is potentially elusive and controversy and debates abound. They speak with Geraldine Doogue.


4.30â5.30 pm: Investigative Journalism
David Marr, Michael Bachelard, Robert Wainright and Paola Totaro discuss their eye-opening research and resulting books, covering the Henson controversy, the Exclusive Brethren, and the Port Arthur massacre.


For venue and booking information visit www.swf.org.au
attributes.content:

Journalism is quickly changing. Reportage and commentary are no longer left to professionals. Instead, âcitizen journalistsâ armed with mobile phone cameras and laptops offer their own views. Should this be celebrated? Or does it raise questions about objectivity? Many welcome the demise of the highly centralised world of journalism, but when anyone can be a news reporter, and professional news reporters seem less than critically minded, how do we know what is true? **1.00â2.00 pm: Losing My Religion**

Ghostlines by Nick Gadd: Book Club Session
Details: Ghostlines, a crime novel by Yarraville resident Nick Gadd, opens with a train accident at the notorious Yarraville train station level crossing and follows suburban journalist Philip Trudeau on an investigation that involves the Melbourne art world. Both Yarraville and Footscray feature heavily throughout the book. Nick Gadd shows Yarraville in both the present day and in the 1950s, when the suburb was a known industrial area.


To book, visit the Williamstown Literary Festival website: http://www.willylitfest.org.au/
attributes.content:
**Ghostlines by Nick Gadd: Book Club Session**
Details: _[Ghostlines](http://www.scribepublications.com.au/book/ghostlines)_, a crime novel by Yarraville resident Nick Gadd, opens with a train accident at the notorious Yarraville train station level crossing and follows suburban journalist Philip Trudeau on an investigation that involves the Melbourne art world. Both Yarraville and Footscray feature heavily throughout the book. Nick Gadd shows Yarraville in both the present day and in the 1950s, when the suburb was a known industrial area.

To book, visit the Williamstown Literary Festival website: http://www.willylitfest.org.au/
attributes.title: Book Club Session: Ghostlines, at Williamstown Literary Festival

Please join the Eltham College of Education on Sorry Day, Monday 1 June to hear:
Dr Tony Birch
Lecturer, Creative Writing, School of Culture and Communication, University of Melbourne

In this talk Tony Birch, author of Shadowboxing, will reflect on the concepts of forgiveness, apologies, responsibility and importantly, recognition. He will particularly talk about how these themes inform his short fiction. Tony will read short excerpts from his writing and invite discussion from the audience.

Free entry
Bookings essential: 03 9439 8700, elthambookshop@bigpond.com.


Presented by the Nillumbik Reconciliation Group, ELTHAM_bookshop_, Australian Indigenous Studies, Faculty of Arts, University of Melbourne, and Scribe, as part ‘The Past Matters 2009’.
To see the full Past Matters 2009 programme, please click here.
attributes.content:

He will particularly talk about how these themes inform his short fiction. Tony will read short excerpts from his writing and invite discussion from the audience.

Free entry
Bookings essential: 03 9439 8700, elthambookshop@bigpond.com.

attributes.content_markup:
The art of the novel
Kevin Rabalais, author of The Landscape of Desire

This workshop will help you enhance your novel-writing skills and polish your first novel. We will focus on essential aspects of fiction writing and examine plot, structure, rhythm and characterisation. The workshop will teach us how to identify problems in our own fiction so that we may seek solutions. In the process, the workshop will help us discover the importance of reading like a writer in order to write the book that weâve always had in mind.

Venue: Verandah Room, Byron Community & Cultural Centre, Jonson Street, Byron Bayl

To book visit: www.byronbaywritersfestival.com
attributes.content:
**The art of the novel**
Kevin Rabalais, author of _[The Landscape of Desire](http://www.scribepublications.com.au/book/thelandscapeofdesire)_

This workshop will help you enhance your novel-writing skills and polish your first novel. We will focus on essential aspects of fiction writing and examine plot, structure, rhythm and characterisation. The workshop will teach us how to identify problems in our own fiction so that we may seek solutions. In the process, the workshop will help us discover the importance of reading like a writer in order to write the book that weâve always had in mind. attributes.content_markup:
Lamar Waldron on The Long Shadow of the JFK Assassination

Lamar Waldron, author of Legacy of Secrecy: the long shadow of the JFK assassination, was called ‘the ultimate JFK historian and examiner’ by Variety. His groundbreaking research has been featured by hundreds of newspapers and radio stations, and was the subject of the Discovery Channel documentary, Conspiracy Files: JKF Assassination. He has been featured on CNN, the History Channel, Geraldo Rivera, and Fox News. His work has been acclaimed by authors ranging from former FBI agent William Turner to Kennedy biographer John H. Davis. Session hosted by Russ Radcliffe.

Crime & Justice Festival
The Abbotsford Convent, 1 St Heliers Street, Abbotsford
For tickets visit: http://www.crimeandjusticefestival.com/
attributes.content:
**Lamar Waldron on The Long Shadow of the JFK Assassination** Lamar Waldron, author of _[Legacy of Secrecy: the long shadow of the JFK assassination](http://www.scribepublications.com.au/book/legacyofsecrecy)_, was called 'the ultimate JFK historian and examiner' by _Variety_. His groundbreaking research has been featured by hundreds of newspapers and radio stations, and was the subject of the Discovery Channel documentary, _Conspiracy Files: JKF Assassination_. He has been featured on CNN, the History Channel, Geraldo Rivera, and Fox News. His work has been acclaimed by authors ranging from former FBI agent William Turner to Kennedy biographer John H. Davis. Session hosted by Russ Radcliffe. Crime & Justice Festival
The Abbotsford Convent, 1 St Heliers Street, Abbotsford
For tickets visit: [http://www.crimeandjusticefestival.com/](http://www.crimeandjusticefestival.com/)
attributes.title: Lamar Waldron at the Crime & Justice Festival

attributes.content_markup:
Testimonies: Witnessing Life

‘Writers trouble themselves, rightly, about the usefulness of writing in troubled times-and times are always troubled.’ Do books have the power to effect social, personal and historical change? How are personal memoirs and biographies of other people journeys that bring our humanity home to us? In Bitter Shore, journalist and human rights lawyer Jacquie Everitt, presents the tragic story of young Shayan Badraieâs Iranian refugee family. Hear Jacquieâs journey as a writer of a story that breaks her heart even as she speaks about it.

Chair: Julian Burnside, QC, author of Wordwatching and Watching Brief: reflections on human rights, law, and justice

Entry: $5.00 per session. Full Festival $20.00. Lunch $10.00.

Bookings are essential for each session. To book email ELTHAMbookshop@bigpond.com.
attributes.content:
**Testimonies: Witnessing Life**
'Writers trouble themselves, rightly, about the usefulness of writing in troubled times-and times are always troubled.' Do books have the power to effect social, personal and historical change? How are personal memoirs and biographies of other people journeys that bring our humanity home to us? In _Bitter Shore_, journalist and human rights lawyer Jacquie Everitt, presents the tragic story of young Shayan Badraieâs Iranian refugee family. Hear Jacquieâs journey as a writer of a story that breaks her heart even as she speaks about it.
Chair: [Julian Burnside](http://www.scribepublications.com.au/author/julianburnside), QC, author of _[Wordwatching](http://www.scribepublications.com.au/book/wordwatching1)_ and _[Watching Brief: reflections on human rights, law, and justice](http://www.scribepublications.com.au/book/watchingbrief1)_
Entry: $5.00 per session. Full Festival $20.00. Lunch $10.00.
Bookings are essential for each session. To book email ELTHAMbookshop@bigpond.com.
attributes.title: Julian Burnside at New Voices 2009 Festival

attributes.content_markup:
True Stories: Windows on the World

Another perspective on the connections between story and history. Do writers effect change by being both witness and agent of historical circumstance? How do personal accounts relate to historical event? And when it comes to finely observed truth, the writerâs subject doesnât get much finer than microbes: what is their story? Roger Averill, Boy, He Cry, L M Robinson, Madame Brussels, Lorraine Campbell, Resisting the Enemy, Idan Ben-Barak, Small Wonders: How Microbes Rule Our World explore historical intersections, scientific truths and shades of non fiction.
Chair: Kevin Rabalais, The Landscape of Desire

Entry: $5.00 per session. Full Festival $20.00. Lunch $10.00.

Bookings are essential for each session. To book email ELTHAMbookshop@bigpond.com.
attributes.content:
**True Stories: Windows on the World** Another perspective on the connections between story and history. Do writers effect change by being both witness and agent of historical circumstance? How do personal accounts relate to historical event? And when it comes to finely observed truth, the writerâs subject doesnât get much finer than microbes: what is their story? Roger Averill, _Boy, He Cry_, L M Robinson, _Madame Brussels_, Lorraine Campbell, _Resisting the Enemy_, Idan Ben-Barak, _[Small Wonders: How Microbes Rule Our World](http://www.scribepublications.com.au/book/smallwonders)_ explore historical intersections, scientific truths and shades of non fiction.
Chair: Kevin Rabalais, _[The Landscape of Desire](http://www.scribepublications.com.au/book/thelandscapeofdesire)_ Entry: $5.00 per session. Full Festival $20.00. Lunch $10.00. Bookings are essential for each session. To book email ELTHAMbookshop@bigpond.com.
attributes.title: Idan Ben-Barak and Kevin Rabalais at New Voices 2009 Festival

Murder, Mirth and Mayhem

Humour can often be found in the darkest of places and crime is no exception. Robert Gott’s novels always come with a wry smile and Shirley Hardy-Rix loves to collect bizarre stories of crime gone tragically, but also humorously wrong. Today they talk to Simon Clews about why crime can often so damn funny!

Crime & Justice Festival
The Abbotsford Convent, 1 St Heliers Street, Abbotsford
For tickets visit: http://www.crimeandjusticefestival.com/

attributes.content:
**Thrills, Spills and International Intrigue** The thriller is an extremely popular form and one of its exponents currently enjoying great success is Mark Abernethy. Today he talks to [Robert Gott's](http://www.scribepublications.com.au/author/robertgott) about his work. Crime & Justice Festival
The Abbotsford Convent, 1 St Heliers Street, Abbotsford
For tickets visit: [http://www.crimeandjusticefestival.com/](http://www.crimeandjusticefestival.com/)
attributes.title: Robert Gott at the Crime & Justice Festival

attributes.content_markup:
Free Spin: controlling the Message and the Limits of Free Speech

Panellists: Natasha Stott Despoja, Fred Chaney, George Megalogenis, MC Mehta, Zainah Anwar

Freedom of information laws are in place at state and federal level in Australia, yet all we seem to get is spin. Governments in continuous campaign mode relentlessly massage the message and journalists chase the daily grab rather than getting to grips with substance. Our libel laws remain among the most restrictive in the world, yet at the same time we get tangled up in acrimonious debates about censorship and freedom of expression. Is our speech free enough? Are we too timid and polite? Or would a free speech free-for-all create more losers than winners?

Visit the 2009 Adelaide Festival of Ideas website for more information.
attributes.content:

Freedom of information laws are in place at state and federal level in Australia, yet all we seem to get is spin. Our libel laws remain among the most restrictive in the world, yet at the same time we get tangled up in acrimonious debates about censorship and freedom of expression. Is our speech free enough? Are we too timid and polite? Or would a free speech free-for-all create more losers than winners?

Does the end justify the means?

Counterinsurgency expert and author of The Accidental Guerilla, David Kilcullen and Julian Burnside, a barrister and human rights advocate, make for an explosive combination when discussing if the end ever justifies the means.

Our restless life

Is it possible to have too much choice? Do we have a glut of information but never go into a library? Do we travel the world but never learn another language? Do we chop and change faiths depending on what our current needs are? John Carroll, author of Ego and Soul and Brigid Delaney discuss if we sacrifice depth for breadth.

Date: 22 Aug 2009
Time: 4:00pm – 5:00pm
Venue: BMW Edge, Federation Square

The secrets of memoir writing – truth or consequences?
Workshop with Wayson Choy, Canada

Professor Wayson Choy has taught memoir writing classes at the University of Toronto and at Humber College, and his most recent book, Not Yet, is a beautiful work of creative non-fiction. Join Professor Choy as he delves into memoir writing, helping participants to explore the tensions of this delicate craft. Professor Choy will help nurture and explore each studentâs own talents and will help them recognize their own particular process.

Time: From 10 A.M. – 4 P.M.
Duration: 6hrs
Venue: RMIT Room 4.3.11
Cost: $195/$175

To book visit Melbourne Writers Festival website: http://www.mwf.com.au

Is The Pen Mightier Than The Stethoscope?

Apollo managed to combine a dual career as the Greek god of both poetry and medicine. Copernicus, Maimonides, Bulgakov and Chekhov were all physicians who purloined their patientsâ narratives.

Leah Kaminsky talks to award-winning doctor-writers Ethan Canin, Peter Goldsworthy and Jacinta Halloran author of Dissection, about their own experiences of medicine and the muse.

To commemorate the 10-year anniversary of the East Timor referendum for independence, Ballarat Australia East Timor Association presents the launch of Balibo by Jill Jolliffe.

Balibo will be launched to coincide with the premiere of the Australian film Balibo, starring Anthony LePaglia. The film is based on Jillâs book.

In addition to speaking of her experiences researching the 1975 killing of the Balibo Five as director of the Living Memory Project, Jill will talk about her work documenting the stories of East Timorese political prisoners.

Portico Wine Bar & Restaurant
203 Dana St, Ballarat
http://www.porticobar.com.au

RSVP: andrewmiller@ballarat.vic.gov.au or nicole.wiseman@gmail.com by Friday 14 August. Please indicate if you will be attending just the launch or launch and dinner.

[_Balibo_](http://www.scribepublications.com.au/book/balibofilmtieinedition) will be launched to coincide with the premiere of the Australian film _Balibo_, starring Anthony LePaglia. The film is based on Jillâs book.

attributes.content_markup:
Masterclass: Peeling Back the News

Take a CNN news clip and unpeel it until its true ugly face shines through. Dutch journalist Joris Luyendiijk spent five years as the youngest ever correspondent to the Middle East, culminating in his new book Fit to Print: misrepresenting the Middle East. He shows through powerful examples and great humour how the media gives us a filtered and manipulated image of reality. This hands-on workshop provides new insights into media led reporting.

For more information visit the Brisbane Writers Festival website: http://www.brisbanewritersfestival.com.au
attributes.content:

Dutch journalist Joris Luyendiijk spent five years as the youngest ever correspondent to the Middle East, culminating in his new book _[Fit to Print: misrepresenting the Middle East](http://www.scribepublications.com.au/book/fittoprint)_. He shows through powerful examples and great humour how the media gives us a filtered and manipulated image of reality. This hands-on workshop provides new insights into media led reporting.

View from the Middle East

Sydney born Irfan Yusuf decided he should die for a Muslim cause. Joris Luyendijk spent five years as the youngest ever Middle East correspondent, culminating in his new book Fit to Print: misrepresenting the Middle East. Abbas El-Zein grew up in war torn Lebanon. Lana Å lezic has published Forsaken a photographic essay of her two-year assignment in Afghanistan.
Chair: Matt Peacock

For more information visit the Brisbane Writers Festival website: http://www.brisbanewritersfestival.com.au

‘Beyond Balibo’
Clinton Fernandes @ Underground Talk

Clinton Fernandes was consulting historian to the film Balibo. In this Underground Talk, he will expand upon the issues raised in the film, including the role of the Australian government, the solidarity movement that developed here â and the ongoing struggle for justice in East Timor today.

Clinton Fernandes is Senior Lecturer in Politics at the Australian Defence Force Academy. He is the author of Reluctant Saviour: Australia, Indonesia and the independence of East Timor, and Reluctant Indonesians: Australia, Indonesia and the future of West Papua.

Entry: $5.00/ $2.00
To book or for more information: 03 9662 3744, nibs@nibs.org.au

attributes.content_markup:
The UQ School of Journalism and Communication invites you to attend:

Reporting Islam: representation and reality

Dutch journalist Joris Luyendijk, in Australia for the Brisbane Writers Festival, will join industry contemporaries and academics from the School of Journalism and Communication to explore how the media reporting of Islam is subject to filters, causing incongruence between what is happening on the ground and what people around the world are being told.

In his most recent book, Fit to Print: misrepresenting the Middle East, Joris writes about the five years he spent as a correspondent in the Middle East and Africa. The youngest ever correspondent and fluent in Arabic, he spoke with stone-throwers and terrorists, with taxi drivers and professors, with victims and aggressors, and their families. An enormous gap yawned between what he saw as a correspondent on the ground and what he saw in the media.

The panel will discuss the reasons that this might happen and whether on balance any type of alteration is needed, desired or necessary, or should the right to know be regarded as an inalienable right that should not be subject to filter or change.

As well as Joris Luyendijk the panel will consist of:

Anthony Frangi – Broadcasting Program Director and Industry Consultant in the School of Journalism and Communication.
Dr John Harrison – UQ Lecturer in Communication and Public Relations.
John Birmingham – Published author and freelance journalist.

When: Thursday 10 September 2009, 5:30pm – 7:30pm
Where: Terrace Room, Level 6, Sir Llew Edwards Building (14), Campbell Road, The University of Queensland

RSVP (by Monday 7 September 2009) to Gordon Lynn on 07 3346 7967 or g.lynn@uq.edu.au

Light refreshments will be served

In his most recent book, _[Fit to Print: misrepresenting the Middle East](http://www.scribepublications.com.au/book/fittoprint)_, Joris writes about the five years he spent as a correspondent in the Middle East and Africa. The youngest ever correspondent and fluent in Arabic, he spoke with stone-throwers and terrorists, with taxi drivers and professors, with victims and aggressors, and their families. An enormous gap yawned between what he saw as a correspondent on the ground and what he saw in the media.

attributes.content_markup:
The Arts Don’t Deserve a Place at This Festival

The arts have run out of dangerous ideas – all the taboos have been broken, and there is nothing shocking left to say. Nothing visionary, or even important. Does anyone still think you can change society with better architecture?

The ABC’s Stephen Crittenden hosts a discussion between sociology professor and author of The Wreck of Western Culture John Carroll; The Chaser’s Julian Morrow; and The Age columnist Catherine Deveny.

The arts are sometimes described as a safe place to raise dangerous issues, but are they really nothing more than a harmless consolation for the middle class? And if the Arts are supposed to be challenging, who and what are they challenging?

Perhaps the arts are no more a civilising influence than sausages.

Venue: Drama Theatre, Sydney Opera House

For more information visit the Festival of Dangerous Ideas website.
attributes.content:
**The Arts Don't Deserve a Place at This Festival**

The arts have run out of dangerous ideas - all the taboos have been broken, and there is nothing shocking left to say. Nothing visionary, or even important. Does anyone still think you can change society with better architecture?

The ABC's Stephen Crittenden hosts a discussion between sociology professor and author of _[The Wreck of Western Culture](http://www.scribepublications.com.au/book/thewreckofwesternculture)_ [John Carroll](http://www.scribepublications.com.au/author/johncarroll); The Chaser's Julian Morrow; and _The Age_ columnist Catherine Deveny.

The arts are sometimes described as a safe place to raise dangerous issues, but are they really nothing more than a harmless consolation for the middle class? And if the Arts are supposed to be challenging, who and what are they challenging?

Perhaps the arts are no more a civilising influence than sausages.

Venue: Drama Theatre, Sydney Opera House

For more information visit the Festival of Dangerous Ideas [website](http://www.sydneyoperahouse.com/whatson/theartsdontdeserveaplaceatthisfestival.aspx).
attributes.title: John Carroll at the Festival of Dangerous Ideas

To celebrate the launch of two great cartoon collections:

Matt Goldingâs new book Three-Second Thoughts
& Russ Radcliffeâs annual Best Australian Political Cartoons 2009

A panel of some of Australiaâs sharpest and wittiest cartoonists will talk about their favourite political cartoons of the year, the difference between gag and political cartooning, what makes a great cartoon, the sources of creativity in cartooning, and whatever else comes up.

Matt Golding: editorial cartoonist Sunday Age, Melbourne Weekly, Three-Second Thoughts
Firstdogonthemoon (aka Andrew Marlton): editorial cartoonist for crikey.com
Mark Knight: editorial cartoonist Herald Sun
Russ Radcliffe: editor of Best Australian Political Cartoons 2009
Chaired by Peter Mares: presenter of The National Interest, ABC Radio National

time: 6.15 for 6.30 pm, Thursday 26 November 2009
at: Village Roadshow Theatrette, State Library of Victoria, Entry 3, Latrobe Street, Melbourne
free but bookings essential: by Monday 23 November 2009 to Readings 03 9347 6633

attributes.content_markup:
Small wonders: how microbes rule our world
Idan Ben-Barack and Clare Peddie

Did you know that your currently carrying at least a kilo of bacteria around on (and in!) you at the moment? And that without these hitchhikers we’d get very sick, very quickly? The world is a very different place if you are a bacteria or virus, who can happily live in the most extreme environments on earth, from deep-sea volcanoes to boiling hot sulphur ponds. Join us for an evening with Idan Ben-Barak, author of Small Wonders: how microbes rule our world as he talks to Advertiser Science Reporter Clare Peddie about how different our lives might be without our microscopic friends.

Venue: RiAus, Science Exchange, Adelaide
Date: Thursday 12 November
Time: 6.30â8.00 pm
Cost: $10/7 (Members and concessions)
For more information click here.

The RiAus is also proudly supporting Small Wonders events for young people at Tea Tree Gully Library and Pt Adelaide Enfield Library on Friday 13 November.
attributes.content:
**Small wonders: how microbes rule our world**
Idan Ben-Barack and Clare Peddie

Did you know that your currently carrying at least a kilo of bacteria around on (and in!) you at the moment? And that without these hitchhikers we'd get very sick, very quickly? The world is a very different place if you are a bacteria or virus, who can happily live in the most extreme environments on earth, from deep-sea volcanoes to boiling hot sulphur ponds. Join us for an evening with Idan Ben-Barak, author of _[Small Wonders: how microbes rule our world](http://www.scribepublications.com.au/book/smallwonders)_ as he talks to _Advertiser_ Science Reporter Clare Peddie about how different our lives might be without our microscopic friends.

Venue: RiAus, Science Exchange, Adelaide
Date: Thursday 12 November
Time: 6.30â8.00 pm
Cost: $10/7 (Members and concessions)
For more information [click here](http://www.riaus.org.au/events/2009/november/small_wonders_how_microbes_rule_our_world.jsp).

The RiAus is also proudly supporting _[Small Wonders](http://www.scribepublications.com.au/book/smallwonders)_ events for young people at Tea Tree Gully Library and Pt Adelaide Enfield Library on Friday 13 November.

attributes.content_markup:
Things you can do to get the best out of the genetic hand you have been dealt

Lifestyle and Environment have become buzzwords in the discussion about good health. In this workshop Dr Carole Hungerford, author of Good Health in the 21st Century, will discuss practical applications of the information arising from her talk. Patients often feel overwhelmed at the thought of how to get started, but the reality is quite simple. What to include in the diet, what to avoid in the diet, and what to avoid around the house. The use of supplements will also be discussed. Useful references will be given, and questions will be answered.

More about the conference…

PROFOUND HEALING – SUSTAINABLE WELLBEING ANNUAL CONFERENCE
SATURDAY 14 & SUNDAY 15 NOVEMBER at Hilton on the Park, Melbourne

Make a difference to your life!
Take an active role in your Health, Happiness and Wellbeing

12 KEYNOTE SPEAKERS & 12 INTERACTIVE WORKSHOPS
Assoc Prof Nick Allen, Dr Tania Ash, Dr Grant Blashki, Dr Ruth Gawler, Dr Ian Gawler, Dr Caig Hassed, Dr Carole Hungerford, Chris James, Petrea King, Prof Ian Olver, Prof Avni Sali, Swami Shankarananda, Swami Devi Ma, Sally White and Dr Michelle Woolhouse

PANEL DISCUSSION: Integrative Cancer Management – challenges, opportunities and vision for the future
Panellists: Prof Ian Olver (CEO Cancer Council Australia), Dr Ian Gawler, Dr Craig Hassed and Petrea King
Moderator: Jon Faine (774 ABC Melbourne)

Actively participate, listen and learnâ¦

Two Days $330 Gawler Foundation Members $300 Concession $280 (includes morning/afternoon teas and lunch)

Conference brochure available online at www.gawler.org
attributes.content:
**Things you can do to get the best out of the genetic hand you have been dealt**

Lifestyle and Environment have become buzzwords in the discussion about good health. In this workshop Dr Carole Hungerford, author of _[Good Health in the 21st Century](http://www.scribepublications.com.au/book/goodhealthinthe21stcentury1)_, will discuss practical applications of the information arising from her talk. Patients often feel overwhelmed at the thought of how to get started, but the reality is quite simple. What to include in the diet, what to avoid in the diet, and what to avoid around the house. The use of supplements will also be discussed. Useful references will be given, and questions will be answered.

*More about the conference...*

**PROFOUND HEALING - SUSTAINABLE WELLBEING ANNUAL CONFERENCE**

THE UNIVERSITY OF MELBOURNE PUBLISHING & COMMUNICATIONS PROGRAMME’S ANNUAL DEBATE

In an age in which authors, readerships and the publishing industry in general are increasingly globalised, can anyone still aspire to write (much less publish) the ‘Great Australian Novel’?

for the … AFFIRMATIVE

Aviva Tuffield (Commissioning Editor, Scribe)
Robert Sessions (Publishing Director, Penguin Australia)
Jessie Mawson (current student)

for the … NEGATIVE

Professor Ken Gelder (Melbourne University)
Chris Flynn (Editor, Torpedo)
Nicole Eckersley (current student)

Come along to find out, over drinks and nibblies, at:

Time: 6.00 pm, Wednesday 2 December
Venue: Multifunction Room, 1888 Building, Melbourne University, Parkville Campus
RSVP: By 25 November to Dr Hugh McNaughtan, h.m@unimelb.edu.au (gates 7/8, near corner of Grattan and Swanson Streets)

attributes.content_markup:
Some international commentators have expressed dismay that Australia is still debating climate change while other developed and developing economies have moved on and are already making positive steps towards climate change strategies. Is Australia out of step with the rest of the world? Whoâs telling fibs and whoâs providing facts about climate change in Australia? Have the Australian people switched off?

On 25 November 2009 at 12.30 pm the ANU Climate Change Institute will host the event Too Hot To Talk About: Why is Australia Still Debating Climate Change? The event will be a Q & A style event zeroing in on how climate change is communicated to Australians – the spin, the noise, the clutter as well as the facts.

Participating in the event will be Crikeyâs Canberra Correspondent Bernard Keane, Dr Will Grant â Lecturer from the ANU Centre for the Public Awareness of Science, Simon Grose â Canberra Press Gallery correspondent for Science Media, Dr onacloV â Artist and Lecturer from the Design Lab at University of Sydney and award-winning author Tony Kevin â author of Crunch Time: using and abusing Keynes to fight the twin crises of our era. Prof Will Steffen, Executive Director of the ANU Climate Change Institute, will moderate the event.

The event will be live streamed on the Internet. Follow the link from the ANU homepage next week (www.anu.edu.au). You can interact with comments and questions on the Livestream page or through Twitter with the tag #climatedebate.

The event is free and open to the public, but seating at the event is strictly limited. To reserve your seat contact ANU Climate Change Institute on 02 6125 56599 / http:www.anu.edu.au/climatechange

attributes.content_markup:
On the anniversary of the Federal Governmentâs apology to the Stolen Generations, The Wheeler Centre presents a night of celebration and reflection, sharing the common and different experiences that define our past and our present.

Twelve of Australiaâs best writers come together for an intimate night of storytelling, each reflecting on those tales that have been handed down to them through the generations, each giving voice to an inheritance of wisdom, of understanding, of identity.

With contributions from Chloe Hooper, Paul Kelly, Cate Kennedy, Judith Lucy, Shane Maloney, David Malouf, John Marsden, Alex Miller, John Safran, Christos Tsiolkas, Tara June Winch and Alexis Wright this will be a literary event like no other.

Join us as we reflect on the stories that make us who we are and mark the arrival of The Wheeler Centre.

Venue: Melbourne Town Hall, 90-120 Swanston Street, Melbourne, 3000
Tickets & Bookings: $15 adult/ $5 concession.

For more information and to book visit The Wheeler Centre.

attributes.content_markup:
For almost 500 years, the Jews of Europe were kept apart, confined to ghettos or tiny villages in the countryside. Then, in one extraordinary moment in the French Revolution, the Jews of France were emancipated. Soon the ghetto gates were opened all over Europe. The era of Emancipation had begun. What happened next would change the course of history.

Author, journalist and broadcaster, Michael Goldfarb, will discuss his new book Emancipation: how liberating Europe’s Jews from the ghetto led to revolution and renaissance at:

Time: 6.00 for 6.30 pm
Date: Thursday 18 February
Venue: Avid Reader Bookshop, 193 Boundary Street, West End, Qld
Tickets: $5.00
Bookings: RSVP essential. Phone 07 3846 3422 or email events@avidreader.com.au

What happened next would change the course of history.

attributes.content_markup:
David Finkel, author of the critically acclaimed The Good Soldiers, will discuss his book with Eric Campbell from ABC’s Foreign Correspondent.

Presented by Gleebooks and the Walkley Foundation

Date: Thursday 4 March, 6.30 for 7.00 pm
Venue: gleebooks, 49 Glebe Point Rd, Glebe
Cost: $10/$7 conc. gleeclub welcome
Book: gleebooks 02 9660 2333 or visit their website.

It was the last-chance moment of the war. In January 2007, President George W. Bush announced a new strategy for Iraq. It became known as ‘the surge’. ‘Many listening tonight will ask why this effort will succeed when previous operations to secure Baghdad did not. Well, here are the differences’, he told a sceptical nation. Among those listening were the young, optimistic army infantry soldiers of the 2-16, the battalion nicknamed the Rangers. About to head to a vicious area of Baghdad, they decided the difference would be them.

Fifteen months later, the soldiers returned home forever changed.

What is the true story of the surge? And was it really a success? Those are the questions that the Pulitzer Prize-winning Washington Post reporter David Finkel grapples with in his remarkable report from the front lines. He was with Battalion 2-16 in Baghdad almost every gruelling step of the way.

Combining the action of Mark Bowden’s Black Hawk Down with the literary brio of Tim O'Brien’s The Things They Carried, The Good Soldiers is an unforgettable work of reportage. And in telling the story of these good soldiers, the heroes and the ruined, Finkel has also produced an eternal tale â not just of the Iraq War, but of all wars, for all time.

‘From a Pulitzer Prize-winning writer at the height of his powers comes an incandescent and profoundly moving book: powerful, intense, enraging. This may be the best book on war since the Iliad.’ Geraldine Brooks, author of People of the Book

‘An extremely fluent and vivid, and compulsively readable, piece of work.’ Owen Richardson, The Age

‘The most honest, most painful, and most brilliantly rendered account of modern war I’ve ever read.’ Fortune Magazine

David Finkel is the national enterprise editor of The Washington Post. He joined the Post in 1990 and has worked for the paper’s national, foreign, and magazine staffs. He has reported from Africa, Asia, Central America, Europe, and throughout the United States, and was part of the Post’s war coverage in Iraq, Afghanistan, and Kosovo. Among Finkel’s journalism honours are a Pulitzer Prize for explanatory reporting in 2006 for a series of stories about U.S.-funded democracy efforts in Yemen. He has been a Pulitzer finalist three other times, for both explanatory reporting and feature writing. A 1977 graduate of the University of Florida, Finkel is married, has two daughters, and lives in Silver Spring, Maryland.
attributes.content:

**David Finkel** is the national enterprise editor of _The Washington Post_. He joined the _Post_ in 1990 and has worked for the paper's national, foreign, and magazine staffs. He has reported from Africa, Asia, Central America, Europe, and throughout the United States, and was part of the _Post's_ war coverage in Iraq, Afghanistan, and Kosovo. Among Finkel's journalism honours are a Pulitzer Prize for explanatory reporting in 2006 for a series of stories about U.S.-funded democracy efforts in Yemen. He has been a Pulitzer finalist three other times, for both explanatory reporting and feature writing. A 1977 graduate of the University of Florida, Finkel is married, has two daughters, and lives in Silver Spring, Maryland.
attributes.title: David Finkel discusses The Good Soldiers at Readings Hawthorn

attributes.content_markup:
Nick Gadd, author of the award-winning novel Ghostlines, will be discussing his favourite books on his ‘bedside table’.

Date: Tuesday 9 February, 7.00 pm
Venue: Altona Library, 123 Queen Street
Free but bookings essential: Phone 03 9932 1330 or email library@hobsonsbay.vic.gov.au
For more information visit: hobsonsbaylibraries.vic.gov.au

The Bedside Books Club is a partnership between State Library of Victoria and Hobsons Bay Libraries and the concept is a guest writer and a guest reader talk about the books on their bedside table and then the discussion is opened up to the audience to talk about one that they have loved.

Winner of 2009 Ned Kelly Award, Best First Fiction
Shortlisted for the Aurealis Awards 2008
Winner of the 2007 Victorian Premierâs Literary Award for an unpublished manuscript

‘Ghostlines is rough cut, grainy and good â¦ earthy and exciting, with a bluesy, wistful air.’ â Kathy Hunt (Australian)

A thriller with a neat psychological twist, Gadd’s Trudeau is a convincing central character whose own story is just as compelling as the mystery at the heart of the story … Gadd neatly avoids the cliches of the genre â Trudeau may fit the crime fiction mould, but his story and personality is strong enough to stand on its own.‘ â Sadie Killen (Herald Sun)

‘With Ghostlines and the Trudeau character, Gadd has created an opportunity for a series of novels, perhaps even a rival for Shane Maloney’s wonderful and wonderfully funny Murray Whelan series.’ â Seamus Bradley (Sunday Age, Read of the Week)

‘Nick has written a crisp, clever, economical, satisfyingly rounded crime thriller. And not just an effective thriller, but a good book â¦ Nick writes in a lean, stripped-down prose, shorn of ornamentation and effect. He has written about a journalist; but he’s also written like a journalist, at least an old-fashioned one before real estate became such an important consideration.’ â Gideon Haigh

‘This is an atmospheric, intriguing and spooky debut by a Melbourne writer who won last year’s Victorian Premier’s Literary Award.’ â Frank Walker (Sun Herald)

‘Trudeau is a marvellously flawed hero, driven by the ghosts of this past and mired in a world where everything is falling apart around him … Crime fans will enjoy the compelling narrative, the succinct writing and the pleasing lack of blood, gore and psychopathic behaviour that mars most contemporary crime stories. I suspect and hope that this isnât the last we see of Trudeau. FOUR STARS’ â (Bookseller & Publisher)

Ghostlines ‘packs a very strong narrative punch as it tells the story of a one-time respected investigative journalist who has stepped on the wrong toes … Strong dialogue, a tight structure, and an exceptional narrative voice take the reader on a journey to a provocative conclusion.’ â Judges, Victorian Premier’s Literary Awards

Opening Event: The State of the Nation or “Here’s Another Fine Mess We’ve Gotten Ourselves Into”

Taking a long hard look at Australia today will be columnist and agitator Catherine Deveny, writer Tony Kevin whose latest book, Crunch Time looks to John Maynard Keynes for an answer to our economic situation, historian Richard Evans who writes on the disasters that changed Australia, former detective-turned-author Clive Small and social commentator Anne Manne. Where are we at now, how did we get here and where should we be heading next?

For more information or to book, visit the Writers at the Convent website: www.writersattheconvent.com

Tony Kevin on Crunch Time

As the world struggles with twin economic and environmental crises, a new urgency has entered into discussions about what needs to be done. Author Tony Kevin says we have reached a crunch time and we need to apply the genuine, profound insights of John Maynard Keynes to help feed and employ us while we reinvent Australia as a renewable energy-based economy that will sustain our children’s and grandchildren’s climate security.

For more information or to book, visit the Writers at the Convent website: www.writersattheconvent.com

attributes.content_markup:
Michael Goldfarb on Emancipation

For almost 500 years, the Jews of Europe were kept apart, confined to ghettos or tiny villages in the countryside. Then, in one extraordinary moment in the French Revolution, the Jews of France were emancipated. Soon the ghetto gates were opened all over Europe. The era of Emancipation had begun. What happened next would change the course of history. Michael Goldfarb looks at how liberating Europe’s Jews from the ghetto led to revolution and renaissance.

For more information or to book, visit the Writers at the Convent website: www.writersattheconvent.com

What happened next would change the course of history. [Michael Goldfarb](http://www.scribepublications.com.au/author/michaelgoldfarb) looks at how liberating Europe's Jews from the ghetto led to revolution and renaissance.

attributes.content_markup:
The Kevin Performance Index

…or why I want Kevin Rudd to shut up for just one day so I can clear the backlog in my inbox. He is talking and typing faster than any leader I have covered, and I admit I canât keep up. My gripe is not with him. Iâll explain how the information age has turned our leaders into permanent celebrities, and the 24-hour news cycle has driven the incumbent PM to a high water mark of gibberish.

George Megalogenis is the author of Faultlines (Scribe 2003) and The Longest Decade (Scribe 2006, updated 2008) and a senior journalist with The Australian newspaper.

Venue: The Wheeler Centre Auditorium, 176 Little Lonsdale Street, Melbourne
Date: Thursday 4 March, 12.45â1.05 pm
To book: FREE! No bookings necessary

About Lunchbox/Soapbox

Lunchbox/Soapbox is a simple idea; an old-fashioned Speakersâ Corner in the middle of the city, in the middle of the day. Think of it as a 20-minute piece of polemic to give lunching CBD folk something to chew on. Bring your lunch along to this bite-sized session.

For more information visit The Wheeler Centre website.

...or why I want Kevin Rudd to shut up for just one day so I can clear the backlog in my inbox. He is talking and typing faster than any leader I have covered, and I admit I canât keep up. My gripe is not with him. Iâll explain how the information age has turned our leaders into permanent celebrities, and the 24-hour news cycle has driven the incumbent PM to a high water mark of gibberish.

Venue: The Wheeler Centre Auditorium, 176 Little Lonsdale Street, Melbourne Date: Thursday 4 March, 12.45â1.05 pm To book: FREE! No bookings necessary

attributes.content_markup:
About Debut Mondays
Readers are spoilt for choice: bookshops are overflowing with the great, the good (and the rest), and it could not be harder to choose what to read next. And let’s face it, a first-time local writer isn’t guaranteed of a guest spot on Rove, or the high-profile national tour.

Every fortnight, let DEBUT MONDAYS be your guide. Come and have a glass of wine and discover the best new writers around.

This event features: Poetry Slam champ Ezra Bixâs Dancing in the Lifeboat, Christine Darcasâs debut novel Dancing in High Heels Backwards, Alzheimerâs: A Love Story by prize-winning short story writer Vivienne Ulman and Damon Youngâs Distraction.

Venue: The Wheeler Centre Auditorium, 176 Little Lonsdale Street, Melbourne

To book: FREE! For bookings (recommended) or for further information, visit The Wheeler Centre website.
attributes.content:
**About Debut Mondays**
Readers are spoilt for choice: bookshops are overflowing with the great, the good (and the rest), and it could not be harder to choose what to read next. And let's face it, a first-time local writer isn't guaranteed of a guest spot on _Rove_, or the high-profile national tour.
Every fortnight, let DEBUT MONDAYS be your guide. Come and have a glass of wine and discover the best new writers around.
This event features: Poetry Slam champ Ezra Bixâs _Dancing in the Lifeboat_, Christine Darcasâs debut novel _Dancing in High Heels Backwards_, [_Alzheimerâs: A Love Story_](http://www.scribepublications.com.au/book/alzheimersalovestory) by prize-winning short story writer Vivienne Ulman and Damon Youngâs _Distraction_.
Venue: The Wheeler Centre Auditorium, 176 Little Lonsdale Street, Melbourne
To book: FREE! For bookings (recommended) or for further information, visit The Wheeler Centre [website](http://wheelercentre.com/calendar/event/debut-mondays2/).
attributes.title: Vivienne Ulman at The Wheeler Centre

attributes.content_markup:
Writersâ influences extend far beyond the things they read. The creative impulse is driven by experience, by people theyâve met, places theyâve been and, in many cases, the music theyâve listened to.

In partnership with Melbourne’s iconic 3RRR, The Writer’s Mix Tape is an exploration of the music that has run through our writersâ lives.

Each month a different 3RRR broadcaster will interview a notable writer about the songs that have most moved and shaped their career. Short snippets from the songs will be interspersed between intimate chat, outlining personal and writerly connections to each piece of music.

Playwrights and poets, novelists and essayists, with some of Melbourneâs finest broadcasters we dig a little deeper to find the soundtrack to their creative and professional lives.

Date: Tuesday 25 May 2010, 6.00â7.00 pm
Venue: The Wheeler Centre Auditorium, 176 Little Lonsdale Street, Melbourne
Bookings: This is a free event, but booking is recommended.
For more information or to make a booking visit The Wheeler Centre website.
attributes.content:
Writersâ influences extend far beyond the things they read. The creative impulse is driven by experience, by people theyâve met, places theyâve been and, in many cases, the music theyâve listened to.
In partnership with Melbourne's iconic 3RRR, The Writer's Mix Tape is an exploration of the music that has run through our writersâ lives.
Each month a different 3RRR broadcaster will interview a notable writer about the songs that have most moved and shaped their career. Short snippets from the songs will be interspersed between intimate chat, outlining personal and writerly connections to each piece of music.
Playwrights and poets, novelists and essayists, with some of Melbourneâs finest broadcasters we dig a little deeper to find the soundtrack to their creative and professional lives.
Date: Tuesday 25 May 2010, 6.00â7.00 pm Venue: The Wheeler Centre Auditorium, 176 Little Lonsdale Street, Melbourne Bookings: This is a free event, but booking is recommended. For more information or to make a booking visit The Wheeler Centre [website](http://wheelercentre.com/calendar/event/the-writer-s-mix-tape-max-barry-with-rob-jan/).

Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist David Finkel spent eight months with 800 US army infantry soldiers in Iraq during President Bush’s infamous campaign ‘the surge’. Reporting from the front line he captures the lives of ordinary men enduring extraordinary circumstances in a defining moment in history. His outstanding book was named one of The New York Times' top ten books of 2009.

When: Sat 27 Feb, 6.30pm
Venue: Octagon Theatre, University of Western Australia
Price: $21.50, Friends $19, Students $15.55
To book: Visit Perth Writers Festival website.

In a twenty year career, Michael Goldfarb covered many different conflicts, with different causes â Northern Ireland, Israel/Palestine, Iraq/Kurdistan â but they all had one thing in common: they were civil wars in all but name. In this lecture he will reflect on what the tipping points are that lead a society to civil war and then lead the warriors to genocide at:

Time: 2.00 pm
Date: Friday 19 February
Venue: Forgan Smith Building (Building 1), Lecture Theatre E301, The University of Queensland, St Lucia
Bookings: Free but please RSVP essential
For more information contact Deborah Mayersen at d.mayersen@uq.edu.au

In this lecture he will reflect on what the tipping points are that lead a society to civil war and then lead the warriors to genocide at:

attributes.content_markup:
Jill Jolliffe, author of Balibo will talk about how she has been following the Balibo Five story for 34 years. She has a long association with East Timor and witnessed the first incursions of Indonesian regular troops into East Timor in September 1975, ans how she had to report the death of her five colleagues at Balibo.

Over the years, she has maintained an unwavering commitment to bringing out the truth about what happened to them on that mid-October morning.

Northern Territory Library
Parliament House

Free event â open to the public.
Bookings preferred 1800 019 155
attributes.content:

She has a long association with East Timor and witnessed the first incursions of Indonesian regular troops into East Timor in September 1975, ans how she had to report the death of her five colleagues at Balibo.
Over the years, she has maintained an unwavering commitment to bringing out the truth about what happened to them on that mid-October morning.
Northern Territory Library

attributes.content_markup:
Translating Milena Agus’s The House in Via Manno with Brigid Maher

Presented by the Italian Institute of Culture, Melbourne, Scribe Publishing.

This presentation explores some of the challenges â both linguistic and cultural â of translating Milena Agusâs novel into English. The translator, Brigid Maher, discusses her decision to use selected Italian, Sardinian and dialectal words in the translation so as to give a sense of place, and the way the Australian audienceâs background knowledge or stereotypes of Italy might be exploited in order to emphasize the bookâs cultural origins.

Brigid Maher teaches Italian language, culture and translation at La Trobe University. In 2008 she completed her doctoral thesis, which explored the translation of humour in Italian and English literature.

Date: Thursday 29 April 2010, 7.00pm
Venue: Italian Institute of Culture, 233 Domain Road, South Yarra
Language: English
Admission: Free
Bookings: essential on (03) 9820 2054 or bookings.iicmelbourne@esteri.it
attributes.content:

_Presented by the Italian Institute of Culture, Melbourne, Scribe Publishing._
This presentation explores some of the challenges â both linguistic and cultural â of translating Milena Agusâs novel into English. The translator, Brigid Maher, discusses her decision to use selected Italian, Sardinian and dialectal words in the translation so as to give a sense of place, and the way the Australian audienceâs background knowledge or stereotypes of Italy might be exploited in order to emphasize the bookâs cultural origins.
Brigid Maher teaches Italian language, culture and translation at La Trobe University. In 2008 she completed her doctoral thesis, which explored the translation of humour in Italian and English literature.
Date: Thursday 29 April 2010, 7.00pm Venue: Italian Institute of Culture, 233 Domain Road, South Yarra Language: English Admission: Free Bookings: essential on (03) 9820 2054 or bookings.iicmelbourne@esteri.it

attributes.content_markup:
ALR: What’s Wrong with Anzac?

Few would disagree that in recent years the idea of the Anzac has become an important, even dominant force within Australian history. But with Anzac Day just around the corner, what does it all really mean?

At the special event, presented in partnership with The Australian Literary Review, a panel of historians and commentators explore the historical fact and the mythology surrounding Anzac.

Featuring Whatâs Wrong with Anzac? lead authors, Professors Marilyn Lake and Henry Reynolds and historian Ross McMullin. Chaired by the ALRâs Stephen Romei.

This is a free event. Bookings recommended: http://wheelercentre.com/calendar/event/alr-what-s-wrong-with-anzac/

Ross McMullin is the author several books, including Pompey Elliott, and Will Dyson: Australia’s radical genius.
attributes.content:
**ALR: What's Wrong with Anzac?**
Few would disagree that in recent years the idea of the Anzac has become an important, even dominant force within Australian history. But with Anzac Day just around the corner, what does it all really mean?
At the special event, presented in partnership with _The Australian Literary Review_, a panel of historians and commentators explore the historical fact and the mythology surrounding Anzac.
Featuring _Whatâs Wrong with Anzac?_ lead authors, Professors Marilyn Lake and Henry Reynolds and historian Ross McMullin. Chaired by the ALRâs Stephen Romei.
This is a free event. Bookings recommended: <http://wheelercentre.com/calendar/event/alr-what-s-wrong-with-anzac/>
Ross McMullin is the author several books, including [_Pompey Elliott_](http://www.scribepublications.com.au/book/pompeyelliott1), and [_Will Dyson: Australia's radical genius_](http://www.scribepublications.com.au/book/willdyson).
attributes.title: Ross McMullin at the Wheeler Centre

Shining a spotlight onto non-fiction. Write What You Know is an opportunity to learn the ins and outs of professional writing.

Our panellists will discuss how they got started in their field, the challenges and opportunities of their writing forms, and speak broadly about their experiences in the industry. Questions encouraged!

Featuring: David Carlin, Hazel Edwards and Louise Wilson.
Hosted by: Sam Cooney.

Date: Monday 24 May, 6.00â7.00 pm
Venue: The Wheeler Centre, 176 Little Lonsdale Street, Melbourne
Prices: Tickets $20 full / $10 concession
For more information: Visit emergingwritersfestival.org.au

attributes.content_markup:
Blogs, twitter novels, mobile phone stories, online op-eds â¦ The internet is a vast writing space. How different is writing for an online audience, and why would you choose the medium? Will it ever be considered ârealâ writing, and how lucrative is it financially?

Panellists: Max Barry, Mel Campbell, Rachael Kendrick and Philip Thiel. Hosted by: Jeremy Balius.

Date: Saturday 29 May, 12.30 pm
Venue: Melbourne Town Hall, Cnr Swanston and Collins Streets
Prices: Weekend pass $45 full / $30 concession, day pass $35 full / $25 concession
For more information: Visit emergingwritersfestival.org.au
attributes.content:

attributes.content_markup:
Sure they say write what you know, but whether youâre writing fiction or memoir, it isnât always easy drawing material from your own life. These writers discuss how they feel when people read their words, and how they deal with the fallout of their confessions. And what happens when people mistake your characters for you?

Panellists Jon Bauer, Samone Bos, Benjamin Law and Lou Sanz.
Hosted by Caro Cooper.

Date: Saturday 29 May, 3.00 pm
Venue: Melbourne Town Hall, Cnr Swanston and Collins Streets
Prices: Weekend pass $45 full / $30 concession, day pass $35 full / $25 concession
For more information: Visit emergingwritersfestival.org.au

attributes.title: Mining the Personal with Jon Bauer

attributes.content_markup:
Our writers discuss the importance of location in their writing. Is a sense of place important, how do you capture it, and do you have a responsibility to represent places or times in certain ways? And what if the place youâre writing about doesnât even exist â¦?

Panellists Patrick Cullen, Leanne Hall, Sean Riley and Jenny Sinclair.
Hosted by Angela Meyer.

Date: Sunday 30 May, 3.00 pm
Venue: Melbourne Town Hall, Cnr Swanston and Collins Streets
Prices: Weekend pass $45 full / $30 concession, day pass $35 full / $25 concession
For more information: Visit emergingwritersfestival.org.au

attributes.content_markup:
Scribe is delighted to invite you to the launch of

Indelible Ink
a novel by Fiona McGregor

to be launched by Paul Kelly, Singer/Songwriter

Date: Thursday 8 July
Time: 6.00 for 6.30 pm
Venue: Readings Carlton, 300 Lygon Street, Carlton VIC
RSVP: shornbeck@scribepub.com.au or 03 9349 5955

‘For a long time now, when people ask me a favourite Australian author, invariably I think and say Fiona McGregor. There is a gutsiness, a splendour and command of language and expression in her writing that thrills me every time I read her. Indelible Ink is a stunning book, a novel that addresses our world and our time with an acute and ferocious acumen. There is also tenderness here and there is wisdom. Marie King, the grandmother who begins to understand living and courage with her first tattoo, is destined to become one of the great characters of Australian literature. This is a superb book by â undeniably now â one of our finest writers. Thanks for publishing this book. It’s f**king gold.’ â Christos Tsiolkas
attributes.content:

attributes.content_markup:
Club writers – Book Talk

Presented by: Guest reviewers Kirsty Murray and Sonia Orchard. Hosted by Nick Gadd.

Join special guest host Nick Gadd and authors Kirsty Murray and Sonia Orchard who will be reviewing the controversial book The Good Man Jesus and the Scoundrel Christ by Philip Pullman (Text release May 2010). Be prepared for lively debate as this book may incite diverse opinions. Audience members will be invited to join in the discussion.

The Good Man Jesus and the Scoundrel Christ will startle and enthrall. It may be the most controversial reworking of the Jesus story since The Last Temptation of Christ. Avowed athiest and bestselling writer Philip Pullman pulls the curtain away from the greatest mystery of all â the resurrection of Jesus Christ.

In this ingenious and spellbinding tale, Philip Pullman reimagines the most influential story ever told. Charged with mystery, compassion and great power, The Good Man Jesus and the Scoundrel Christ offers a fresh perspective on who Jesus was and asks questions that will resonate long after the book has been read.

Sonia Orchard is a freelance writer and author. She has written for a range of magazines and publications, including The Age Cheap Eats, Wellbeing, Surfgirl and the Lonely Planet guide books. In February 2002, Sonia published her first book Something More Wonderful (Hodder Headline Australia)

Kirsty Murray writes fiction for younger readers and teenagers. Her novels have won and been short-listed for numerous awards including the WA Premierâs Award and the NSW Premierâs History Award. She has been an Asialink Literature resident at the University of Madras in India and a Creative Fellow of the State Library of Victoria. Her published works include nine novels, several works of non-fiction and two junior fiction titles. www.kirstymurray.com

Nick Gaddâs first novel, Ghostlines, published by Scribe won a Victorian Premierâs Literary Award in 2007 and a Ned Kelly Award for best first fiction in 2009. He currently teaches Novel in the Diploma of Professional Writing and Editing at Box Hill TAFE.

Venue: Victorian Writers Centre, The Wheeler Centre, 176 Little Lonsdale Street, Melbourne
For more information visit: http://vwc.org.au/what-s-on/event/club-writers-book-talk1/
attributes.content:

attributes.content_markup:
Club writers – Book Talk

Featuring Jarad Henry and Cate Kennedy with Host, Nick Gadd.
Venue: Victorian Writers Centre, The Wheeler Centre, 176 Little Lonsdale Street, Melbourne
For more information visit: http://vwc.org.au/what-s-on/event/club-writers-book-talk2/

Nick Gadd will be stepping in Elly Varrentiâs shoes for this month only as special guest host for Julyâs Club writers â Book Talk session. Be prepared for lively debate with an opportunity for audience members to join in the discussion. Guest reviewers Jarad Henry and Cate Kennedy will discuss our featured book of the month, Siberian Education by Nicolai Lilin and translated by Jonathon Hunt. (Text release June, 2010)

Nicolai Lilinâs memoir is an account of a young boy growing up in a world that is strangely recognisable, yet different to anything we have experienced. Controversial, brutally honest and sometimes disturbing, Siberian Education takes the reader to a place no other writer has been.

Jarad Henry has worked in the criminal justice system for the past ten years and is currently a strategic adviser for Victoria Police. He has a degree in Criminology, is a proficient public speaker and is a regular presenter at conferences, forums and seminars on crime trends. Head Shot, a murder mystery inspired by Melbourneâs gangland killings, was short listed in the 2006 Ned Kelly Awards for Best First Crime Novel. Blood Sunset is his second book and focuses on the street sex trade in St Kilda. It was short listed in the 2006 Australian Vogel Awards and in the same year won the Fellowship of Australian Writers Jim Hamilton Award. More recently it was runner up in the 2008-09 Summer Read Program. He lives in Melbourne and is currently working on his third novel, Pink Tide.

Cate Kennedy has won several awards for her short fiction and her 2006 collection Dark Roots was shortlisted for the Australian Literature Gold Medal and the Queensland Premierâs Awards. Her stories have appeared in publications as diverse as The Big Issue and The New Yorker. Her most recent work is a novel, The World Beneath, published by Scribe in September 2009. She is an experienced workshop leader who has also worked as a fiction judge, writer-in-residence, mentor and editor.

Nick Gaddâs first novel, Ghostlines, published by Scribe won a Victorian Premierâs Literary Award in 2007 and a Ned Kelly Award for best first fiction in 2009. He currently teaches Novel in the Diploma of Professional Writing and Editing at Box Hill TAFE.

attributes.content_markup:
Unhappily, many people for whom language is a central part of their lifeâs work are a bit careless about the way they use it. Go into any court or any parliament any day and see whether you find the language inspiring, or even intelligible. If we were carpenters, we would probably leave our hammer and saw in the rain. The point of language is to convey meaning. Ideally, it should do so accurately. Not all writers honour this ideal. The purpose of language may be betrayed by carelessness, foolishness or malevolence, by representatives of big business, bureaucrats and politicians.

Julian Burnside will speak about each, and will finish with some recent reminders that language can be used powerfully and effectively if only we take enough care.

Time: 12.45â1.45 pm, Thursday 3 June
Venue: The Wheeler Centre Auditorium, 176 Little Lonsdale Street, Melbourne
For more information visit: http://wheelercentre.com

The point of language is to convey meaning. Ideally, it should do so accurately. Not all writers honour this ideal. The purpose of language may be betrayed by carelessness, foolishness or malevolence, by representatives of big business, bureaucrats and politicians.

Time: 12.45â1.45 pm, Thursday 3 June Venue: The Wheeler Centre Auditorium, 176 Little Lonsdale Street, Melbourne For more information visit: [http://wheelercentre.com](http://wheelercentre.com)
attributes.title: Lunchbox/Soapbox: Julian Burnside: Mind Your Language

attributes.content_markup:
What is justice? How does our legal system work? How can we trust a system that is so changeable and widely criticised? And are our laws really effective? These are some of the fundamental questions that former Supreme Court judge Ken Crispin sets out to answer. The themes will be idiosyncratic: from pop-cultural analysis to high cultural criticism; from political grandstanding to personal mischief-making. But theyâll all be thought-provoking. Bring your lunch along to this bite-sized session.

Date: 12.45â1.15 pm, Thursday 1 July
Venue: The Wheeler Centre Auditorium, 176 Little Lonsdale Street, Melbourne
For more information visit http://wheelercentre.com

A memoir is a cumulative narrative that ultimately proffers some revelation or illumination. This session showcases two ingenious and insightful writers: David Carlin, Our Father Who Wasnât There and Vivienne Ulman, Alzheimerâs: A Love Story.
