attributes.content_markup:
How to cool the planet: geoengineering and the audacious quest to fix the earthâs climate

Right now, a group of scientists is working on ways to minimise the catastrophic impact of global warming. But theyâre not designing hybrids or fuel cells or wind turbines. Theyâre trying to lower the temperature of the entire planet. And theyâre doing it with huge contraptions that suck CO2 from the air, machines that brighten clouds and deflect sunlight away from earth, even artificial volcanoes that spray heat-reflecting particles into the atmosphere. This is the field of geoengineering, seen as fringe science, the realm of sci-fi only a few years ago, the field is now a serious topic of research in labs across the globe.

But what price will resetting the thermostat come at? Join us as author Jeff Goodell, author of How to Cool the Planet‘ and Sam Doust from ABCâs project Bluebird explore just what it might take to engineer a solution to climate change.

Date: 6.00 pm, Wednesday 21 July
Venue: RiAus @ The Science Exchange, Exchange Place, Adelaide
For more information visit: www.riaus.org.au
attributes.content:
**How to cool the planet: geoengineering and the audacious quest to fix the earthâs climate**
Right now, a group of scientists is working on ways to minimise the catastrophic impact of global warming. But theyâre not designing hybrids or fuel cells or wind turbines. Theyâre trying to lower the temperature of the entire planet. And theyâre doing it with huge contraptions that suck CO2 from the air, machines that brighten clouds and deflect sunlight away from earth, even artificial volcanoes that spray heat-reflecting particles into the atmosphere. This is the field of geoengineering, seen as fringe science, the realm of sci-fi only a few years ago, the field is now a serious topic of research in labs across the globe.
But what price will resetting the thermostat come at? Join us as author **Jeff Goodell**, author of _[How to Cool the Planet](http://www.scribepublications.com.au/book/howtocooltheplanet)_' and **Sam Doust** from ABCâs project Bluebird explore just what it might take to engineer a solution to climate change.
Date: 6.00 pm, Wednesday 21 July Venue: RiAus @ The Science Exchange, Exchange Place, Adelaide For more information visit: [www.riaus.org.au](http://www.riaus.org.au)
attributes.title: Jeff Goodell on Geoengineering: RiAus, Adelaide

attributes.content_markup:
How to Cool the Planet: geoengineering and the audacious quest to fix Earth’s climate

Time: 6.00 for 6.30â8.00 pm, Tuesday 20 July
Venue: Avid Reader Bookshop, 193 Boundary Street, West End
Tickets $5.00, RSVP essential
Book online or email events@avidreader.com.au or phone (07) 3846 3422

When Jeff Goodell first encountered the term ‘geoengineering’, he had a vague sense that it involved outlandish schemes to counteract global warming. As a journalist, he was deeply sceptical. But he was also intrigued. The planet was in trouble. Could geo-engineers help?

Climate change may well be the biggest crisis humanity has ever faced. Temperatures in some regions of the world could increase by as much as fifteen degrees by the end of the century, causing rising sea levels and severe droughts. But change could also happen much more suddenly. What if we had a real climate emergency, the ecological equivalent of the subprime mortgage meltdown â how could we cool the planet in a hurry?

As Goodell shows in this bracing book, even if we could muster the political will for it, cutting greenhouse gas emissions alone may not be enough to reduce the risk of climate catastrophe. This has led some scientists to pursue extreme solutions: huge contraptions that would suck CO2 from the air, machines that would brighten clouds and deflect sunlight away from the earth, even artificial volcanoes that would spray heat-reflecting particles into the atmosphere.

In How to Cool the Planet, Goodell explores the scientific, political, financial, and moral aspects of geo-engineering. Thoroughly reported and convincingly argued, How to Cool the Planet is a compelling tale of scientific hubris and technical daring. But it is also a thoughtful, even-handed look at a deeply complex and controversial issue. It’s a book that will surely jump-start the next big debate about the future of life on earth.
attributes.content:
**How to Cool the Planet: geoengineering and the audacious quest to fix Earth's climate**
Time: 6.00 for 6.30â8.00 pm, Tuesday 20 July Venue: Avid Reader Bookshop, 193 Boundary Street, West End Tickets $5.00, RSVP essential Book [online](http://www.avidreader.com.au/index.php?option=com_registrationpro&view=event&did=60&Itemid=0&shw_attendees=0) or email events@avidreader.com.au or phone (07) 3846 3422
***
When Jeff Goodell first encountered the term 'geoengineering', he had a vague sense that it involved outlandish schemes to counteract global warming. As a journalist, he was deeply sceptical. But he was also intrigued. The planet was in trouble. Could geo-engineers help?
Climate change may well be the biggest crisis humanity has ever faced. Temperatures in some regions of the world could increase by as much as fifteen degrees by the end of the century, causing rising sea levels and severe droughts. But change could also happen much more suddenly. What if we had a real climate emergency, the ecological equivalent of the subprime mortgage meltdown â how could we cool the planet in a hurry?
As Goodell shows in this bracing book, even if we could muster the political will for it, cutting greenhouse gas emissions alone may not be enough to reduce the risk of climate catastrophe. This has led some scientists to pursue extreme solutions: huge contraptions that would suck CO2 from the air, machines that would brighten clouds and deflect sunlight away from the earth, even artificial volcanoes that would spray heat-reflecting particles into the atmosphere.
In _[How to Cool the Planet](http://www.scribepublications.com.au/book/howtocooltheplanet)_, Goodell explores the scientific, political, financial, and moral aspects of geo-engineering. Thoroughly reported and convincingly argued, How to Cool the Planet is a compelling tale of scientific hubris and technical daring. But it is also a thoughtful, even-handed look at a deeply complex and controversial issue. It's a book that will surely jump-start the next big debate about the future of life on earth.

attributes.content_markup:
9.30am â 12.30pm Verandah Room, Byron Community Centre, Jonson St, Byron Bay $65/$50* Code 14W Max 15 How does a story tell a story?

In this stimulating half-day workshop Cate Kennedy will explore the idea of event and narrative in fiction (or in short fiction) and the way they open up everything that makes a story memorable: character dimension, metaphorical subtext, and satisfying resolution. How does an author decide on what actually happens in a story to reveal these elements to their fullest potential, and how can ordinary life provide the inspiration for these key fictional turning points? If you have felt dissatisfied that your plots and storylines feel too âslightâ to sustain the ideas you want to convey, this workshop will help you refresh your thinking.

Byron Bay Writers Festival
Verandah Room, Byron Community Centre, Jonson Street, Byron Bay
Cost: $65/$50
Tickets: www.byronbaywritersfestival.com, or phone 02 6685 6262

attributes.content_markup:
Not all ethical dilemmas are matters of life and death, but in the world of medicine many of them can be. Every day our doctors and scientists are called on to make judgements and choices, and the moral values that inform them make all the difference. If medical ethics extend beyond the Hippocratic oath, what are the burning considerations and how do they manifest themselves?

Questions of pain management and patients' bills of rights, confidentiality and consent, eugenics and euthanasia, the right to choice and the issue of stem cell research will be considered by our panel of experts. âFirst do no harmâ never seemed so difficult.

Featuring Jacinta Halloran author of Dissection
Chaired by Helen MacDonald

Venue: The Wheeler Centre Auditorium
176 Little Lonsdale Street
Melbourne Victoria 3000

Free, but bookings via the Wheeler Centre website
attributes.content:
Not all ethical dilemmas are matters of life and death, but in the world of medicine many of them can be. Every day our doctors and scientists are called on to make judgements and choices, and the moral values that inform them make all the difference. If medical ethics extend beyond the Hippocratic oath, what are the burning considerations and how do they manifest themselves?
Questions of pain management and patients' bills of rights, confidentiality and consent, eugenics and euthanasia, the right to choice and the issue of stem cell research will be considered by our panel of experts. âFirst do no harmâ never seemed so difficult.
Featuring Jacinta Halloran author of [_Dissection_](http://www.scribepublications.com.au/book/dissection)
Chaired by Helen MacDonald
Venue: The Wheeler Centre Auditorium

Melbourne Victoria 3000
Free, but bookings via the Wheeler Centre [website](http://wheelercentre.com/calendar/event/medical-ethics/)

attributes.content_markup:
An astonishing new scientific discovery called neuroplasticity is overthrowing the centuries old notion that the adult human brain is fixed and unchanging. It is, instead, able to change its own structure and function, even into old age. Psychiatrist and researcher Norman Doidge, MD, travelled around the United States to meet the brilliant scientists championing neuroplasticity, and the people whose lives theyâve transformed.We learn that our thoughts can switch our genes on and off, altering our brain anatomy. We learn how people of average intelligence can, with brain exercises, improve their cognition and perception, and develop muscle strength.

Using personal stories from the heart of this neuroplasticity revolution, Dr Doidge has written an immensely moving, inspiring book that will permanently alter the way we look at our brains, human nature, and human potential.

Date: Wednesday 25 August, 2010
Time: 12:30 PM
Venue: Sofitel Wentworth Hotel 61 Phillip Street, Sydney
Cost: $70 members SMH Dymocks Events. $85 non-members. Includes a two course meal, wine and coffee
Bookings/ Enquiries: 02 9449 4366
For more information visit the Dymocks website

Hosted by Get Reading, Sydney Morning Herald & Dymocks Sydney

attributes.content_markup:
Lessons from the Frontiers of Brain Science

Norman Doidge MD, psychiatrist, psychoanalyst and author, made the discovery of neuroplasticity (the ability of the brain to change itself) understandable for millions of people through his internationally best-selling book The Brain that Changes Itself. In his book, Dr Doidge exposed new discoveries in brain science that found people can change the structure and function of their brains by thinking. This discovery, considered to be the most important breakthrough in our understanding of the human brain in 400 years, is already providing hope for people with learning difficulties, brain injuries, intellectual disabilities, dementia and the elderly.

Dr Doidge will discuss the most recent medical advances resulting from this discovery, including how understanding the brain can unlock the mysteries of love, sexual attraction, taste, culture and education, as well as enable ordinary people to raise their IQ, overcome learning difficulties, become savant calculators, develop muscle strength or learn to play a musical instrument – just by thinking.

An acclaimed international speaker who has addressed the United Nations and Harvard University, Dr Doidge’s seminar is titled ‘Lessons from the Frontiers of Brain Science’ and will be followed by an afternoon session on the neuroscience based computer program Fast ForWord, titled ‘Changing the Brain for Learning’.

The seminars are sponsored by Sonic Learning.

Session 1, 8.30am – 12.30pm; Session 2, 1.30pm 3.00pm

Session 1 (with morning tea) $119.00 incl GST

Sessions 1 & 2 (with morning tea & lunch) $169.00 Incl GST

Includes tea and coffee on arrival and morning tea. Lunch provided for those who enrol in Sessions 1 & 2.

For more information or to book visit UWA Extension or phone 08 6488 2433.

attributes.content_markup:
Scribe and Climate Futures at Macquarie would like to invite you to attend a public forum to discuss the complex issues surrounding geo-engineering.

Jeff Goodell, author of How to Cool the Planet: geoengineering and the audacious quest to fix Earthâs climate, together with climate scientists, will explore the diverse schemes that are now being considered as a response strategy for anthropogenic climate change.

Right now, a group of scientists is working on ways to minimise the catastrophic impact of global warming. But theyâre not designing hybrids or fuel cells or wind turbines. Theyâre trying to lower the temperature of the entire planet. And theyâre doing it with huge contraptions that suck CO2 from the air, machines that brighten clouds and deflect sunlight away from earth, even artificial volcanoes that spray heat-reflecting particles into the atmosphere. This is the field of geoengineering, seen as fringe science, the realm of sci-fi only a few years ago, the field is now a serious topic of research in labs across the globe.

But what price will resetting the thermostat come at? Join us as author Jeff Goodell, author of How to Cool the Planet: geoengineering and the audacious quest to fix Earthâs climate and leading scientists explore just what it might take to engineer a solution to climate change.

Thursday 22 July 2010, 1pm – 2.30pm
Building E6A, Room 102, Macquarie University
RSVP: Monday 19 July 2010
Leigh Staas
Ph: (02) 9850 6297 or
Email: leigh.staas@mq.edu.au
Parking: The university requires people to pay for parking. Casual or short term entry permits are available from ticket dispensing machines near the two main entrances and other identified car parks within the campus.

Right now, a group of scientists is working on ways to minimise the catastrophic impact of global warming. But theyâre not designing hybrids or fuel cells or wind turbines. Theyâre trying to lower the temperature of the entire planet. And theyâre doing it with huge contraptions that suck CO2 from the air, machines that brighten clouds and deflect sunlight away from earth, even artificial volcanoes that spray heat-reflecting particles into the atmosphere. Eight Writers: Eight Ways to be Human

Celebrate the launch of the Melbourne Writers Festival 2010 as we join writers on an unique and creative journey exploring âEight Ways to be Humanâ.

Eight of our festival writers â comprising novelists, scientists, philosophers, memoir writers and playwrights â will share readings from their work, fleshing out the eternal question of what really makes us human.

Norman Doidge, Barry Dickens, Jostein Gaarder, Cate Kennedy, Fiona McGregor, Alex Miller, Nadifa Mohamed and Brenda Walker bring us startling and unexpected insights in an evening laced with wit, sex, tragedy and humour.

Donât miss this amazing line-up â the perfect way to launch ten days of fabulous literary happenings.

Venue: Melbourne Town Hall
For more information click here.

attributes.content_markup:
Motherhood – Not All Nice

Family is a bond of great emotional power, which is inescapable and sometimes dangerous.

Susan Maushart (The Mask of Motherhood), Fiona McGregor (Indelible Ink) and Jon Bauer (Rocks in the Belly) talk about the tremendous life-shaping influences of family.
Chaired by: Jo Case

attributes.content:
**Motherhood - Not All Nice**
Family is a bond of great emotional power, which is inescapable and sometimes dangerous.
Susan Maushart (_The Mask of Motherhood_), **Fiona McGregor** (_Indelible Ink_) and **Jon Bauer** (_Rocks in the Belly_) talk about the tremendous life-shaping influences of family. Chaired by: Jo Case

attributes.content_markup:
Big Ideas: Young People and the Media

Does the Australian media have it in for young people? Who controls how different gender and sexuality groups are represented? As we hurtle towards a digital future, is it realistic to get a job in the media industry beyond 2010?

SBS Producer James West, editor of The Monthly, Ben Naperstek, and controversial writer Emily Maguire field questions from each other, and from you.

Venue: Melbourne Writers Festival, ACMI 2, Federation Square
For more information click here.

attributes.content_markup:
Tokyo Vice

The extortion, racketeering, prostitution and gambling rings associated with Japanâs Yakuza criminal organisations have been written about in books and glorified in films. Until now a substantial first-hand peek inside the insidious underworld by a foreign journalist has not existed. Enter the world of reporter Jake Adelstein, a Jewish-American with an account of his 12-year stint of working the crime beat for the Yomiuri shimbun, Japanâs largest newspaper. He is the author of Tokyo Vice: a Western reporter on the police beat in Japan.

Date: Tuesday 7 September, 7.00 pm
Venue: University Club at UWA
Cost: $29.00
To book visit www.extension.uwa.edu.au or phone 08 6488 2433
Organised by UWA Extension, The University of Western Australia
attributes.content:
**Tokyo Vice**
The extortion, racketeering, prostitution and gambling rings associated with Japanâs Yakuza criminal organisations have been written about in books and glorified in films. Until now a substantial first-hand peek inside the insidious underworld by a foreign journalist has not existed. Enter the world of reporter Jake Adelstein, a Jewish-American with an account of his 12-year stint of working the crime beat for the _Yomiuri shimbun_, Japanâs largest newspaper. He is the author of _Tokyo Vice: a Western reporter on the police beat in Japan_.
Date: Tuesday 7 September, 7.00 pm Venue: University Club at UWA Cost: $29.00 To book visit [www.extension.uwa.edu.au](http://www.extension.uwa.edu.au) or phone 08 6488 2433 Organised by UWA Extension, The University of Western Australia
attributes.title: Jake Adelstein at UWA in Perth

This Thing with Food

Ian Brown is about to commence a journey blogging and eating his way across Canada; while Ramona Koval taces the history of Jewish cuisine as one religion but many food styles. Jaspreet Singh uses an apprentice chef to tell the story of the IndiaâPakistan conflict, and Jake Smith peeks inside the kitchens of the worldâs leaders. What is this obsession with food and food-writing?
Chair: Paul Barclay

Date: 2.30 pm, Sunday 5 September
Venue: The Studio, slq
For more information click here

Brisbane Writers Festival Closing Address

In a very special and exclusive Closing Address, Norman Doidge shares recent film footage of people undergoing neuroplastic change (shown just this once at the Festival) and brings us the updated stories of people benefitting from the neuroplasticity revolution. Norman links science, literature and the celebration of optimism, providing a fitting close to a week of bringing together readers, writers and thinkers from around the world.

Venue: slq Auditorium 1
For more information click here

attributes.content_markup:
Forum: The Future of Fertility

Fertility has become a new issue for couples who have delayed their choice to indulge in that age old biological pursuit â The Family. As both the expectations of older want-to-be parents and improvements to technology diverge and converge well provide some scientific clarity on the questions of reproductive biology and sociology.

How late is too late? What are your choices? Sooner or later?

Reproductive scientists, assisted fertility specialists and parents going through or coming out of the process will give their opinions and insights into this important and difficult topic.

Hosted by Theresa Miller, author of Making Babies: personal IVF stories.

When: Sunday 22 August: 2pm â 4pm
Where: Powerhouse Museum , 500 Harris St, Ultimo
Cost: $20. Booking essential. Call (02) 9217 0222 or book online

Attention potential parents:
Do you want to learn more about fertility? What would you ask a reproductive health expert, an infertility expert, a geneticist or a family with experience of IVF and other fertility treatments?

Email your question to adultlearning@phm.gov.au The best questions will be put to the panel of experts at the forum.

For more information click here
attributes.content:

Fertility has become a new issue for couples who have delayed their choice to indulge in that age old biological pursuit â The Family. As both the expectations of older want-to-be parents and improvements to technology diverge and converge well provide some scientific clarity on the questions of reproductive biology and sociology.
How late is too late? What are your choices? Sooner or later?
Reproductive scientists, assisted fertility specialists and parents going through or coming out of the process will give their opinions and insights into this important and difficult topic.
Hosted by Theresa Miller, author of _[Making Babies: personal IVF stories](http://www.scribepublications.com.au/book/makingbabies)_.
When: Sunday 22 August: 2pm â 4pm Where: Powerhouse Museum , 500 Harris St, Ultimo Cost: $20. Booking essential. Call (02) 9217 0222 or book [online](http://www.powerhousemuseum.com/bookings/usf/fertility.php)

attributes.content_markup:
Authors and Victoria’s Doctors-in-Training Panel Discussion

Come along for a discussion about what it means to be a doctor and a writer, and the relationship between these two identities.

Jacinta Halloran is a Melbourne GP and writer. She has written on medical topics for a wide variety of publications, including the Sunday Age and Inside Story. Her 2007 novel, Dissection, was shortlisted for the Victorian Premierâs Literary Prize for an Unpublished Manuscript, and was published by Scribe Publications in 2008.

Leah Kaminsky was the Eleanor Dark Flagship Fellow for Fiction in 2007 and is the author of three books. She is a practicing family physician.

Serge Liberman works as a medical practitioner. His literary work has been widely published. He is also the author of six collections of short stories, including Where I Stand, three of which received the Alan Marshall Award in their manuscript form.

Date: Tuesday 17 August 2010 at 6:30pm
Venue: Readings Carlton: 309 Lygon St, Carlton, Victoria, 3053
Free, no need to book.
attributes.content:

Her 2007 novel, Dissection, was shortlisted for the Victorian Premierâs Literary Prize for an Unpublished Manuscript, and was published by Scribe Publications in 2008.
Leah Kaminsky was the Eleanor Dark Flagship Fellow for Fiction in 2007 and is the author of three books. She is a practicing family physician.
Serge Liberman works as a medical practitioner. His literary work has been widely published. He is also the author of six collections of short stories, including Where I Stand, three of which received the Alan Marshall Award in their manuscript form.
Date: Tuesday 17 August 2010 at 6:30pm Venue: Readings Carlton: 309 Lygon St, Carlton, Victoria, 3053 Free, no need to book.

attributes.content_markup:
Forum: The Science of Successful Children

The noughties have become the era of a new baby boom. As economic and social pressures increase, families and new parents are stretching to ensure the best for their children. So can science help make a successful child?

Educators, psychologists, nutritionists, developmental biologists and child raising experts will combine forces to provide the truths behind the do and do nots of helping your children to be the best they can be.

Perfect for new and future parents and grand parents entering a seemingly new world of parenting.

Chaired by Theresa Miller, author of Making Babies.

When: Sunday 29 August: 2pm â 4pm
Where: Powerhouse Museum , 500 Harris St, Ultimo
Cost: $20. Booking essential. Call (02) 9217 0222 or book online
For more information click here

Attention parents and carers:
What would you ask a paediatrician, a developmental psychologist, a nutritionist or a gifted and talented educator?

Email your question to adultlearning@phm.gov.au The best questions will be put to the panel of experts at the forum.

Ian Brownâs son, Walker, was born with a genetic mutation so rare that doctors call it an orphan syndrome: perhaps one hundred people around the world live with it. In his moving account, The Boy in the Moon: A Fatherâs Search for His Disabled Son, Brown describes Walkerâs life and how his family help him live it.

The Canadian author and journalist will be in conversation with ABC 774 Melbourne’s Hilary Harper.

Free, but bookings are required: http://wheelercentre.com/calendar/event/the-boy-in-the-moon-ian-brown/
attributes.content:
Ian Brownâs son, Walker, was born with a genetic mutation so rare that doctors call it an orphan syndrome: perhaps one hundred people around the world live with it. In his moving account, [_The Boy in the Moon: A Fatherâs Search for His Disabled Son_](http://www.scribepublications.com.au/book/theboyinthemoon), Brown describes Walkerâs life and how his family help him live it.

attributes.content_markup:
Fiona McGregor will discuss her novel Indelible Ink which uses one family as a microcosm for the changes operating in society at large. On a drunken whim, Marie gets a tattoo â an act that gives way to an unexpected friendship with her tattoo artist, Rhys. Before long, Rhys has introduced Marie to a side of the city that clashes with her staid north-shore milieu. Her children are mortified by their motherâs transformation, but have their own challenges to deal with: workplace politics; love affairs old and new; and, of course, the real-estate market!

Date: Thursday 14 October
Time: 6.00 for 6.30 pm start
Venue: Woollahra Council, 536 New South Head Road, Double Bay
Tickets: $15 pay at the door (Member of Woollahra Library Friends / or concession $10). Reserved tickets not collected by 6pm will be released for general sale. Ticket includes a glass of champagne.
To reserve your seat please contact: 02 9391 7100 or email library@woollahra.nsw.gov.au
attributes.content:
Fiona McGregor will discuss her novel _Indelible Ink_ which uses one family as a microcosm for the changes operating in society at large. On a drunken whim, Marie gets a tattoo â an act that gives way to an unexpected friendship with her tattoo artist, Rhys. Before long, Rhys has introduced Marie to a side of the city that clashes with her staid north-shore milieu. Her children are mortified by their motherâs transformation, but have their own challenges to deal with: workplace politics; love affairs old and new; and, of course, the real-estate market!
Date: Thursday 14 October Time: 6.00 for 6.30 pm start Venue: Woollahra Council, 536 New South Head Road, Double Bay Tickets: $15 pay at the door (Member of Woollahra Library Friends / or concession $10). Reserved tickets not collected by 6pm will be released for general sale. Ticket includes a glass of champagne. To reserve your seat please contact: 02 9391 7100 or email library@woollahra.nsw.gov.au
attributes.title: Fiona McGregor at Woollahra Library

Where does a writer begin writing their novel? Is the first sentence they put on the page the first sentence the reader will read? Where do novels come from? And what does first inspiration look like?

In Westgarth Books first emerging writersâ event, Steven Amsterdam, Chris Womersley, Matt Hooper and Maryrose Cuskelly will join Sydney Smith to discuss âBeginningsâ.

Steven, Chris, Maryrose and Matt will read from their novels and you will be able to ask questions as well as talk about your own experiences in beginning a novel. Authors will also be available for book-signings.

So come along and meet some of Australiaâs most exciting new authors and network with other emerging writers while enjoying cheese and wine and the charm and character of Westgarth Books.

Wine by the glass will be available for purchase with cheese and biscuits on the house. Free but bookings essential. Please RSVP on 03 9482 7117 by Saturday October 9.

attributes.content_markup:
In February 1946, the Australians of the British Commonwealth Occupation Force (BCOF) moved into western Japan to âdemilitarise and democratiseâ the atom-bombed backwater of Hiroshima Prefecture. For over six years, up to 20,000 Australian servicemen, including their wives and children, participated in an historic experiment in nation-rebuilding. It was a cultural reconnaissance â the first time a large number of Australians were able to explore in depth an Asian society and country.

On the evening of Remembrance Day, historian Robin Gerster will discuss his book Travels in Atomic Sunshine: Australia and the occupation of Japan, winner of the 2009 NSW Premierâs History Award for Australian history with Jake Lynch, a former international reporter and peace journalism expert.

Where: Customs House, Circular Quay.

Cost: Free for Library members, $10.00 General, light refreshments included.

Contact: 9242 8555 or library@cityofsydney.nsw.gov.au. Bookings essential.
For more details on the event, click here
attributes.content:
In February 1946, the Australians of the British Commonwealth Occupation Force (BCOF) moved into western Japan to âdemilitarise and democratiseâ the atom-bombed backwater of Hiroshima Prefecture. For over six years, up to 20,000 Australian servicemen, including their wives and children, participated in an historic experiment in nation-rebuilding. It was a cultural reconnaissance â the first time a large number of Australians were able to explore in depth an Asian society and country.
On the evening of Remembrance Day, historian Robin Gerster will discuss his book [_Travels in Atomic Sunshine: Australia and the occupation of Japan_](http://www.scribepublications.com.au/book/travelsinatomicsunshine), winner of the 2009 NSW Premierâs History Award for Australian history with Jake Lynch, a former international reporter and peace journalism expert.
Where: Customs House, Circular Quay.
Cost: Free for Library members, $10.00 General, light refreshments included.
Contact: 9242 8555 or . Bookings essential.
For more details on the event, [click here](http://www.historycouncilnsw.org.au/events/history-conversation)
attributes.title: History Council NSW presents Robin Gerster on Remembrance Day

Writer, editor and broadcaster Sally Warhaft talks to American writer, commentator and journalist, Daniel Akst, about his latest book We Have Met The Enemy: Self Control in an Age of Excess, a witty and wide-ranging investigation into what Akst calls the central problem of our time: how to save ourselves from what we want.

attributes.content_markup:
Daniel Akst on The Age of Excess

US Journalist Daniel Akst has kept his fingers on the American pulse over the years through his writing in, amongst many other publications, The Boston Globe, The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal, Slate Magazine and The Los Angeles Times. With his tongue never far from his cheek, he has written on everything from the loneliness of American society to worshipping the almighty dollar to the hypocrisy of environmentally friendly mansions to the tragic decline of the jock strap. This morning he talks to Meredith Nash about his homeland.

Daniel’s latest book is We Have Met The Enemy: Self Control in an Age of Excess

The Community Room
Abbottsford Convent

To see the full 2011 festival program and information on how to purchase tickets, please check here.
attributes.content:

With his tongue never far from his cheek, he has written on everything from the loneliness of American society to worshipping the almighty dollar to the hypocrisy of environmentally friendly mansions to the tragic decline of the jock strap. This morning he talks to Meredith Nash about his homeland. Author Scott Bennett will give a talk about his new book Pozieres: the Anzac story, at a special pre-Anzac Day presentation.

This account of the PoziÃ¨res battle tells the stories of the men who fought there. Drawing on their letters and diaries, it reveals a battlefield drenched in chaos, suffering, and fear. Bennett sheds light on the story behind the official history, showing how commanders struggled with a war conducted on an unprecedented scale and how the survivors witnessed appalling human tragedy to return home as heroes but, too often, shattered men.

St Kilda Library
150 Carlisle Street
St Kilda VIC 3182

Phone: (03) 9209 6655

attributes.content_markup:
Writers at the Convent â Ways of Seeing â the Role of the Humanities in Public Life

More than ever before, scientific rationalism informs everything we do â from politics and economics to health care, journalism and education. Yet the gulf between the âtwo cultures' â science and the humanities â is widening, and threatens to limit our ability to address complex global and local issues.

To celebrate Ways of Seeing, the latest issue of Griffith REVIEW which addresses this theme, philosopher John Armstrong, writer Peter Ellingsen and physician and author Leah Kaminsky discuss the role of humanities in public life, politics, medicine, the market and the academy. Chaired by Writers at the Convent Creative Programming Director Simon Clews.

The Abbotsford Convent, 1 St Heliers Street, Abbotsford, Melbourne

$17 / $15, bookings: www.writersattheconvent.com or 03 9662 4699
attributes.content:
**Writers at the Convent â Ways of Seeing â the Role of the Humanities in Public Life**
More than ever before, scientific rationalism informs everything we do â from politics and economics to health care, journalism and education. Yet the gulf between the âtwo cultures' â science and the humanities â is widening, and threatens to limit our ability to address complex global and local issues.
To celebrate _Ways of Seeing_, the latest issue of Griffith REVIEW which addresses this theme, philosopher John Armstrong, writer Peter Ellingsen and physician and author Leah Kaminsky discuss the role of humanities in public life, politics, medicine, the market and the academy. attributes.content_markup:
The Greatest Story Never Told: Cate Kennedy in conversation with four fellow writers

Multi-award-winning author Cate Kennedy has invited four fellow writers to join her on the couch. In the Greatest Story Never Told, authors will describe a story they would love to write, but never have, and their reasons.

Carmel Bird is a Tasmanian-born novelist who lives in central Victoria. She has written nine literary novels, six collections of short fiction, three books on the art of writing, and has edited many anthologies of essays and stories. Carmel is sought after as a teacher of fiction writing, and has spoken at major literary events throughout Australia and overseas.

Mark Dapin is an award-winning author and journalist who writes a weekly column for Good Weekend magazine in The Age. His books include the travel bestseller Strange Country, and King of the Cross, which won last yearâs Ned Kelly Award for Best First Fiction.

Jarad Henry has worked in the criminal justice system for more than 10 years, including the past four as a strategy advisor for Victoria Police. Jarad has a degree in criminology, is a regular presenter at many conferences, forums and seminars on crime trends, and is considered an expert on the links between crime and drugs.

Shane Maloney is the creator of the popular Australian crime series â the Murray Whelan novels â for which he was presented with the Crime Writersâ Association of Australia Lifetime Achievement Award in 2009 and the Ned Kelly Award for Best Fiction in 1997.

To find out more or to book see here.
attributes.content:

In the Greatest Story Never Told, authors will describe a story they would love to write, but never have, and their reasons. Carmel Bird is a Tasmanian-born novelist who lives in central Victoria. She has written nine literary novels, six collections of short fiction, three books on the art of writing, and has edited many anthologies of essays and stories. Carmel is sought after as a teacher of fiction writing, and has spoken at major literary events throughout Australia and overseas. Mark Dapin is an award-winning author and journalist who writes a weekly column for Good Weekend magazine in The Age. His books include the travel bestseller Strange Country, and King of the Cross, which won last yearâs Ned Kelly Award for Best First Fiction. Jarad Henry has worked in the criminal justice system for more than 10 years, including the past four as a strategy advisor for Victoria Police. Jarad has a degree in criminology, is a regular presenter at many conferences, forums and seminars on crime trends, and is considered an expert on the links between crime and drugs. Shane Maloney is the creator of the popular Australian crime series â the Murray Whelan novels â for which he was presented with the Crime Writersâ Association of Australia Lifetime Achievement Award in 2009 and the Ned Kelly Award for Best Fiction in 1997. To find out more or to book see [here](http://castlemainefestival.com.au/2011/in-conversation-greatest-story-never-told/).

attributes.content_markup:
The future is far different from anything anyone has ever seen before. Most of us have accepted that our planet is warming and that weâve played the key role in causing climate change. Yet few of us realise the magnitude of whatâs happened.The course we take will affect our civilisation and the planet for millennia. What will that world look like?

Paleoclimatologist Curt Stager vividly shows how what we do to the environment in the 21st century will affect the next 100,000 years of life on this planet.

In the long run, the greatest threat to humans will not be global warming, but global cooling. Just when that âclimate whiplashâ happens is entirely up to us. We have already put off the next Ice Age, but whether our descendents will see an ice-free Arctic, miles of submerged coasts, or an acidified ocean still remains to be decided. Stager shows us how vastly different the world will be if we continue to pollute or if we rein ourselves in for the sake of future generations.

Curt Stager is author of Deep Future: The Next 100,000 Years of Life on Earth. Like the bestsellers The World Without Us and The Next 100 Years, this book offers a new perspective that will change the way climate skeptics, activists, and everyone in between thinks about what weâre doing to our planet.

The University of Western Australia
Social Sciences Lecture Theatre

Cost: $29.00
Bookings can be made via the UWA website.

attributes.content_markup:
Most debate over global warming looks only as far ahead as 2100 AD, but what happens after that? Curt Stager, author of Deep Future: the Next 100,000 Years of Life on Earth argues that our fossil fuel emissions will interfere with the climate for much longer than most of us realise. What will life in the deep future be like? Some will win and some will lose. We’ve already prevented the next ice age, but as the Earth starts to cool down again, “climate whiplash” will force people, animals and plants to reverse their adaptive strategies. Exactly how the future plays out is up to us as we search for a sustainable path forward in this new geologic epoch, the “Age of Humans.”

Pier 2/3 Club Stage, Pier 2/3
Hickson Road
Walsh Bay
attributes.content:

Curt Stager, author of [_Deep Future: the Next 100,000 Years of Life on Earth_ ](www.scribepublications.com.au/book/deepfuture) argues that our fossil fuel emissions will interfere with the climate for much longer than most of us realise. What will life in the deep future be like? Some will win and some will lose. We've already prevented the next ice age, but as the Earth starts to cool down again, "climate whiplash" will force people, animals and plants to reverse their adaptive strategies. Exactly how the future plays out is up to us as we search for a sustainable path forward in this new geologic epoch, the "Age of Humans."

attributes.content_markup:
Is climate change off the political agenda? President Obama didnât even mention it in his State of the Union Address earlier this year. How do we get the action most of us know we need? Naomi Oreskes outlines the dark political forces preventing action. Paleoclimatologist Curt Stager shows the hard choices we have to make now to preserve anything like the planet we know and love. And former director of Greenpeace International and environmental business strategist Paul Gilding argues our economy is on a collision course with nature. Chair: Sam Mostyn.

Sydney Town Hall
483 George Street
Sydney
attributes.content:

attributes.content_markup:
Author Scott Bennett will give a talk about his new book Pozieres: the Anzac story, at a special pre-Anzac Day presentation in Bairndale.

This account of the PoziÃ¨res battle tells the stories of the men who fought there. Drawing on their letters and diaries, it reveals a battlefield drenched in chaos, suffering, and fear. Bennett sheds light on the story behind the official history, showing how commanders struggled with a war conducted on an unprecedented scale and how the survivors witnessed appalling human tragedy to return home as heroes but, too often, shattered men.

Collins Booksellers
166 Main Street
Bairnsdale VIC 3875

Phone: (03) 5152 5181

Cost: $10 (includes light refreshments)
attributes.content:

attributes.content_markup:
Most debate over global warming looks only as far ahead as 2100 AD, but what happens after that? As Curt Stager argues, our fossil fuel emissions will interfere with climates for much longer than most of us, scientists included, yet realize. Even in the best-case scenario, the world won’t fully recover for tens of thousands of years, and possibly much longer. What will life in that shockingly deep future be like? Some will win and some will lose. On the bright side, we’ve already prevented the next nation-crushing ice age. But as the Earth finally starts to cool down again, “climate whiplash” will force people, animals, and plants to reverse their adaptive strategies. Losers may then become winners – but exactly how the future plays out is ultimately up to us as we search for a sane, sustainable path forward in this new geologic epoch, the ‘Age of Humans’.

Stager has taught natural sciences at Paul Smith’s College in the northern Adirondacks since 1987, and is an adjunct professor at the Climate Change Institute, University of Maine, Orono. Since 1990, he has also co-hosted Natural Selections, a weekly science program that is produced and aired by North Country Public Radio. His latest book Deep Future: The Next 100,000 Years of Life on Earth examines the long-term future of global climate change in relation to natural climatic shifts of the past.

Where: Napier lecture theatre G04, Napier Building, University of Adelaide.
Free: Bookings can be made here.

Some will win and some will lose. On the bright side, we've already prevented the next nation-crushing ice age. But as the Earth finally starts to cool down again, "climate whiplash" will force people, animals, and plants to reverse their adaptive strategies. Losers may then become winners - but exactly how the future plays out is ultimately up to us as we search for a sane, sustainable path forward in this new geologic epoch, the 'Age of Humans'. Stager has taught natural sciences at Paul Smith's College in the northern Adirondacks since 1987, and is an adjunct professor at the Climate Change Institute, University of Maine, Orono. Since 1990, he has also co-hosted Natural Selections, a weekly science program that is produced and aired by North Country Public Radio. His latest book [_Deep Future: The Next 100,000 Years of Life on Earth_](http://www.scribepublications.com.au/book/deepfuture) examines the long-term future of global climate change in relation to natural climatic shifts of the past. **Where**: Napier lecture theatre G04, Napier Building, University of Adelaide.
Free: Bookings can be made [here](http://curtstager.eventbrite.com/).
attributes.title: Curt Stager at Adelaide University

attributes.content_markup:
Dumbing Down Democracy: Lindsay Tanner in Conversation with George Megalogenis

In 2010, one of the Wheeler Centreâs most popular events saw former ALP federal minister Lindsay Tanner interview senior political journalist George Megalogenis about his Quarterly Essay. Tanner put Megalogenis under the spotlight, questioning his analysis of the failures of leadership in Australian politics.

In 2011, the tables are turned. The former politician and the respected journalist return to duke it out again, this time focusing on Tannerâs new book Sideshow, part memoir, part analysis, and part critique of the media. In his first book since leaving political life, Tanner lays bare the relentless decline of political reporting and political behaviour that occurred during his career. On media, on politics, on Australia today, Megalogenis and Tanner are a formidable double-act.

Free but bookings required. Bookings can be made here but hurry, it will book out in no time!
attributes.content:

The former politician and the respected journalist return to duke it out again, this time focusing on Tannerâs new book _Sideshow_, part memoir, part analysis, and part critique of the media. In his first book since leaving political life, Tanner lays bare the relentless decline of political reporting and political behaviour that occurred during his career. On media, on politics, on Australia today, Megalogenis and Tanner are a formidable double-act. Free but bookings required. attributes.content_markup:
This year, from May 26 to June 5, Australiaâs premiere celebration of aspiring and emerging writers is on again, with its trademark mix of support and advice, workshops and commiserations for those poor folk who are determined to make a go of being a writer.

But before the 2011 festival kicks off, the Wheeler Centre is proud to present a sneak preview of the kind of chat that will be on offer. Because being a writer is not all about six-figure advances and rapturous signing queues, four of our finest local writers compare notes and gnash their teeth about what itâs really like out there, in the cold, hard world of Writerland. Funny, irreverent, sobering if not sober, this will be a night no new writer can afford to miss.

This event will feature Meg Mundell, author of Black Glass

Bookings can be made here

Larrikinism is a central part of Australian culture but humour has a serious side too. Politicians are often lampooned far worse in pictures than words (just ask former-PM Cyclops Howard!) The Walkley Foundation and the Griffin Press are proud to present this panel discussion on the power of the picture and its potential pitfalls. Join some of Australiaâs best-loved cartoonists, Lindsay Foyle, Alan Moir and Cathy Wilcox, as they take you through their favourite cartoons with âTalking Picturesâ host Mike Bowers.

Alan Moir’s collection of cartoons is Are We Nearly There Yet?.

attributes.content:
Most debate over global warming looks only as far ahead as 2100 AD, but what happens after that? Curt Stager, author of [_Deep Future: the Next 100,000 Years of Life on Earth_](http://www.scribepublications.com.au/book/deepfuture) argues that our fossil fuel emissions will interfere with the climate for much longer than most of us realise. What will life in the deep future be like? Some will win and some will lose. Weâve already prevented the next ice age, but as the Earth starts to cool down again, âclimate whiplashâ will force people, animals and plants to reverse their adaptive strategies. Exactly how the future plays out is up to us as we search for a sustainable path forward in this new geologic epoch, the âAge of Humans.â
Byron Bay Community Centre
69 Jonson Street
Byron Bay NSW 2481
Bookings: 02 6685 5115 Cost - Free
attributes.title: Curt Stager in Byron Bay

Lindsay Tanner in Sideshow: dumbing down democracy lays bare the relentless decline of political reporting and political behaviour that occurred during his career. Part memoir, part analysis, and part critique, Sideshow is a unique book that tackles the rot which has set in at the heart of Australian public life.

Lindsay Tanner was the Minister for Finance and Deregulation in the RuddâGillard governments, and held the seat of Melbourne for the ALP from 1993 to 2010. Having retired from politics at the 2010 federal election, he is now a special adviser to Lazard Australia, and a Vice-Chancellorâs fellow and adjunct professor at Victoria University.

Books will be available for sale and signings will take place after the event.

Venue: Lecture Theatre 1 Manning Clark Centre, ANU

attributes.content_markup:
Panel event with Jacqueline Kent and James Button

Much is written about politics these days. This panel discusses many of the ways this manifests itself and the effects it has. Former minister for finance and regulation in the Rudd-Gillard governments Lindsay Tanner argues in his book Sideshow: dumbing down democracy that the Australian media are gradually retreating from their traditional role of reporting serious political issues to the general public.As their coverage focuses more and more on trivia, gimmicks, and personalities, politiciansâ behaviour is changing to ensure they can still get coverage. A collective effort is needed tore-engage the community with serious debate about major issues.

Woodend Community Centre
Full $15 / Conc $12

attributes.content_markup:
A St Margaret’s Anglican Church, Shire of Nillumbik and ELTHAMbookshop presentation

The sixth annual New Voices 2011 will be held on July 30th -31st

For aspiring writers, book club members, writing groups, poets and readers looking for fresh narratives there is a feast of memoir, fiction, poetry, many many writing tips, time to network, meet independent and leading publishers and a very hip music performance by The Nymphs. The festival will celebrate first time published writers in conversation with award winning, acclaimed thinkers and authors.

On Saturday 30th July at St Margaret’s Anglican Church, the keynote speech will be delivered by Rodney Hall, author of the enchanting ‘Popeye Never Told Me’. Writers featured include David Walker, Gillian Essex, Joel Deane, Josephine Rowe, Meg Mundell, Steve Holden and Mike Pender. Local artist, Ev Hale, will launch her passionate and glorious book, ‘A Life in Process’; Rebus publishing will launch a delightful anthology of poetry, ‘Building Bridges’, presented by Eltham Primary School and no New Voices festival is ever complete without the participation of the intrepid and eloquent Friendly Street Poets who will travel from Adelaide. Our own Suzanne Male, from Yarra Plenty Regional library will provide illuminating literary interludes.

On Sunday 31st July at Montsalvat the piece-de-resistance is the Melbourne launch of Najaf Mazari (The Rugmaker of Mazaar-e-Sharif) and Robert Hillman’s exquisite compilation of tales from Afghanistan, ‘The Honey Thief’. These are tales of leopards that sing and bees that sneeze, of horseshoe bats in flights that blot out the sun, and of blackbirds that bring golden apples to earth from heaven from a land of bloodshed and brotherhood, of miracles and catastrophes.

All through the festival there will be good food, mulled wine and great conversations.
For bookings and program details please contact elthambookshop@bigpond.com
attributes.content:

attributes.content_markup:
Debut Mondays at the Wheeler Centre

Readers are spoilt for choice: bookshops are overflowing with the great, the good (and the rest), and it could not be harder to choose what to read next.

Every fortnight, let Debut Mondays be your guide. Come and have a glass of wine and discover the best new writers around.
This time, weâll be hearing from: Raphael Brous, I am Max Lamm; Melanie Joosten, Berlin Syndrome; Dan Disney, And Then When The; Eli Glasman, âBagâ.

Born in 1981, Melanie Joosten lives and works in Melbourne. She has an Honours degree in Creative Arts and a Master of Arts (Editing) from the University of Melbourne. Berlin Syndrome is her first novel.

This is a free event. No booking required.

attributes.content_markup:
Psychogeography

Psychogeography was first defined in 1955 by French filmmaker Guy Debord as the art of altering audiences' perception of space. Join Chris Womersley, author of the Miles Franklin shortlisted book, Bereft and a panel of other artists as they explore and divulge how they use landscape in their practice to invite, shock, coax or encourage their audience to interact and see their space in new ways. Panellists include artists Reko Rennie, James Geurts and Izabela Pluta.

7pm
Studio 1, ACMI, Federation Square
Full/Concession $6 ACMI Members $5
attributes.content:

Join Chris Womersley, author of the Miles Franklin shortlisted book, [_Bereft_](http://www.scribepublications.com.au/book/bereft1) and a panel of other artists as they explore and divulge how they use landscape in their practice to invite, shock, coax or encourage their audience to interact and see their space in new ways. attributes.content_markup:
Author Talk

Joseph Braude will be at the Surry Hills Library speaking about his new book, The Honoured Dead, a fascinating non-fiction mystery based on Braude’s experiences in Morocco, where he was the first western journalist ever to be embedded in an Arab police force.

Born to an Iraqi-Jewish family, Joseph Braude studied Near Eastern languages at Yale, and Islamic history and Arabic at Princeton. He is fluent in Arabic, Persian, and Hebrew, and has lived, studied, and worked in most Middle Eastern capitals. His journalism has appeared in Best Life, Playboy, and The New Republic, among other publications. He lives in New York.

Free event, bookings essential – please call 02 8374 6230.

5.30pm
Surry Hills Library
405 Crown Street
Surry Hills NSW 2010

attributes.content_markup:
In conversation with Kathy Novak

For centuries, stories of pirates have captured the imagination of people everywhere. But the recent gangs of daring, ragtag pirates off the coast of Somalia, hijacking huge ships owned by international conglomerates, have brought the scourge of piracy into the modern era. While the world sees nothing but opportunistic bands of local bandits running riot, Jay Bahadur, the only Western journalist to venture so deeply into this world, truly sees how it operates.

In Deadly Waters, Bahadur ventures to Puntland, a region in north-eastern Somalia, and tells of the pirates' lives beyond the attack skiffs: how they spend their money, how they think, and why they risk their lives in often suicidal missions. In the remote pirate havens of Somalia, Bahadur sits down and talks with some of the pirates, their cheeks bulging with khat (the local drug of choice), their mobile phones ringing as the men conduct their business. Bahadur also talks to some of the security personnel tasked with combating piracy, as well as with former pirate hostages who lived on their ships for months while awaiting news of a ransom.

Deadly Waters is a major first book by a young freelance journalist who managed to embed himself in one of the worldâs most dangerous places. Jay Bahadur will be in conversation with Kathy Novak, SBS World News Australia presenter and reporter.

6pm
Gleebooks
49 Glebe Point Rd
Glebe, Sydney
$10/$7 conc. Gleeclub welcome
To book contact Gleebooks on 9660 2333 or book online here

attributes.content_markup:
In conversation with Justin Clemens

Weaving together evidence from anthropology, archaeology, primatology, anatomy, and psychosexuality, the authors of this groundbreaking book show how far from human nature monogamy really is.

With intelligence and humour, Ryan and JethÃ¡ explain how our promiscuous past haunts our contemporary struggles. They explore why many people find long-term fidelity so difficult; why sexual passion tends to fade even as love deepens; why homosexuality persists in the face of standard evolutionary logic; and what the human body reveals about the prehistoric origins of modern sexuality.

Shocking, enlightening, and ultimately inspiring, Sex at Dawn offers a revolutionary understanding of why we live and love as we do.

Free event, please book through Readings (03) 93476633

6.30pm
Readings Carlton
309 Lygon Street
Carlton VIC 3053

attributes.content_markup:
In conversation with Leslie Cannold

Susan Mitchell will be speaking about her provocative new book, Tony Abbott: a man’s man.

In Tony Abbot: a man’s man Susan Mitchell explores how Australiaâs would-be prime minister became the man he is today. He is at war, not just with the government, but in an unrelenting battle for the hearts and minds of the Australian people. There is still time, he believes, to achieve the position that his male mentors think he is destined to hold â that of leading the country back to âthe proper order of thingsâ. But is he the prime minister-in-waiting that the country has to have â or does he pose an unacceptable threat to his own party and to the nation?

Dr Susan Mitchell is well known for her ground-breaking, best-selling book Tall Poppies. She has published fourteen books, including a recent biography of Margaret Whitlam. Most of her books have narrated and analysed the lives of women in politics, business, sport, literature, and other major aspects of Australian society. She is adjunct Professor of Creative Writing at Flinders University, a radio and television broadcaster, and a former Opinion and Humour writer for the Australian.

Dr Leslie Cannold is an award-wining author and columnist, as well as a qualified ethicist and researcher. Her latest book is the novel The Book of Rachel.

Free, but please book on 9819 1917

6.30pm
Readings Hawthorn
701 Glenferrie Rd
Hawthorn
Victoria
3122

attributes.content_markup:
Author talk: Lunchbox/Soapbox

Tony Abbott: Too Dangerous to Lead

Ever since Tony Abbott assumed the leadership of the Liberal Party, bipartisanship has all but disappeared. He has created a national political atmosphere that is aggressive, inflammatory, and combative. Why? Because it suits his temperament.

Throughout his life he has been drawn to a series of masculine and Catholic heroes and mentors. As a result, he is a relic of another time. Women are particularly distrustful of his macho image and his combative approach. Underpinning the values of this manâs man is his narrow worldview.

More importantly for the nation, his approach to policy seems to contradict this fixed, rock-solid image. On many issues, in particular climate change,Â­ he constantly slips and slides. This tendency suggests an underlying political opportunism: he is less interested in formulating national policy than in playing divisive politics. He is a leader for himself and for the promulgation of his deeply conservative religious values, and not for the broad interests of the women and men of Australia.

This is a free event. No bookings required.
12:45pm – 1:15pm

The Wheeler Centre
176 Little Lonsdale Street
Melbourne
Victoria 3000

attributes.content_markup:
Who runs the country — the government or the markets?

Barack Obama couldn’t stop Standard and Poor’s downgrading America’s credit rating and in Europe the Greek government is hostage to debt. In his new book, Looking for the Light on the Hill, former Rudd speechwriter and policy adviser Troy Bramston argues Labor needs to refresh its values, philosophy and purpose for the modern era. Fellow panel member Ross Gittins is Economics Editor of the Sydney Morning Herald and author of The Happy Economist, a book that argues for a new way of measuring economic success. In this session chair Linda Funnell will explore both authors' new books and ask them to confront the difficult question of whether the economy is driving politics or if politics is driving the economy.

12:30pm
The Writers Tent
Newtown Festival
Camperdown Memorial Rest Park, bordered by Australia St, Lennox St, Church St and Federation Road.
Newtown
Sydney
NSW 2042

attributes.content_markup:
In conversation with Peter Van Onselen

Troy Bramston will be discussing his new book, Looking for the Light on the Hill: modern Labor’s challenges.

Looking for the Light on the Hill argues that Labor is bedevilled by twin problems: the loss of its intrinsic culture of strong, bold, and innovative leadership; and an identity crisis that has emerged because Labor has failed to refresh its values, philosophy, and purpose for the modern era. Written by party insider and former Rudd government adviser Troy Bramston, the book draws on Laborâs history with fresh perspectives, and includes the secret components of the partyâs recent internal review. It also includes new interviews with former party leaders, current and former ministers, and union leaders and party figures â and reveals astonishing opinion-poll results, commissioned exclusively for this book, that demonstrate the depth of the crisis.

Troy Bramston has worked as a policy and political adviser in government, opposition, and the private sector. He is a former principal speechwriter for Kevin Rudd and an adviser to the Rudd government, and now works in the private sector.

Peter van Onselen is contributing editor at The Australian, writes a weekly column in the News Ltd Sunday papers and hosts Australian Agenda and The Contrarians on Sky News. Dr van Onselen is a Winthrop Professor at The University of Western Australia, and co-authored John Winston Howard: The Biography.

Bookings through http://www.gleebooks.com.au/

6 for 6.30 pm start
Gleebooks,
49 Glebe Point Rd
Glebe
Sydney

It also includes new interviews with former party leaders, current and former ministers, and union leaders and party figures â and reveals astonishing opinion-poll results, commissioned exclusively for this book, that demonstrate the depth of the crisis. Troy Bramston has worked as a policy and political adviser in government, opposition, and the private sector. He is a former principal speechwriter for Kevin Rudd and an adviser to the Rudd government, and now works in the private sector. Peter van Onselen is contributing editor at _The Australian_, writes a weekly column in the News Ltd Sunday papers and hosts _Australian Agenda_ and _The Contrarians_ on Sky News. Dr van Onselen is a Winthrop Professor at The University of Western Australia, and co-authored _John Winston Howard: The Biography_. Bookings through http://www.gleebooks.com.au/
6 for 6.30 pm start
Gleebooks,
49 Glebe Point Rd
Glebe
Sydney
attributes.title: Troy Bramston at Gleebooks

attributes.content_markup:
Breakfast event

Scribe is delighted to announce a very special event. Party insider and former Rudd government adviser Troy Bramston is the author of Looking for the Light on the Hill: modern Labor’s challenges, a book that has already started debates across the nation. Troy argues that Labor is bedevilled by twin problems: the loss of its intrinsic culture of strong, bold, and innovative leadership; and an identity crisis that has emerged because Labor has failed to refresh its values, philosophy, and purpose for the modern era.

Troy Bramston and local Griffith Labor MP Kevin Rudd will be discussing these issues and more over breakfast.

RSVP essential, please call 38998555
8.30am
$35 entry – includes breakfast

attributes.content_markup:
In conversation with Karen Middleton

Foreign correspondent Kim Barkerâs personal account of reporting in Afghanistan and Pakistan, The Taliban Shuffle, is a fiercely honest â and occasionally hilarious â dissection of the absurdities of an intractable conflict. In her book Barker, previously South Asia bureau chief for the Chicago Tribune, abandons the journalistâs conventional poker-faced neutrality for a mordant take on the newest American â and Australian â military quagmire. She will be discussing her experiences with Karen Middleton, author of An Unwinnable War: Australia in Afghanistan and Chief Political Correspondent with SBS television.

This is a free event; bookings are recommended. Book through the Wheeler Centre website here
attributes.content:
**In conversation with Karen Middleton**

In her book Barker, previously South Asia bureau chief for the Chicago Tribune, abandons the journalistâs conventional poker-faced neutrality for a mordant take on the newest American â and Australian â military quagmire. attributes.content_markup:
In conversation with John Safran

In The Young Atheistâs Handbook Alom Shaha, a BritishâBangladeshi film-maker, science writer and unabashed atheist argues that regardless of the strictness of the traditions you are raised in, itâs possible to live a compassionate, fulfilling, and meaningful life without God. He’ll be discussing this, and how atheists can break free from inherited beliefs, with broadcaster and provocateur John Safran.

This is a free event; bookings are recommended. Book through the Wheeler Centre website here

6.15pm

attributes.content_markup:
Special Radio National live recording with Paul Barclay

A true-life Catch-22 set in the war-torn countries of Afghanistan and Pakistan, by one of the region’s longest-serving correspondents.

Kim Barker is not your typical, impassive foreign correspondentâshe is candid, self-deprecating, laugh-out-loud funny. At first an awkward newbie in Afghanistan, she grows into a wisecracking, seasoned reporter with grave concerns about US forces' ability to win hearts and minds in the region. In The Taliban Shuffle, Barker offers an insider’s account of the ‘forgotten war’ in Afghanistan and Pakistan, chronicling the years after America’s initial routing of the Taliban.

When Barker arrives in Kabul, foreign aid is at a record low, electricity is a pipe dream, and of the few remaining foreign troops, some aren’t allowed out after dark. Meanwhile, in the vacuum left by the US and NATO, the Taliban is regrouping.

Tickets are $5. Book through the Avid Reader website here
attributes.content:
**Special Radio National live recording with Paul Barclay**
A true-life Catch-22 set in the war-torn countries of Afghanistan and Pakistan, by one of the region's longest-serving correspondents. Kim Barker is not your typical, impassive foreign correspondentâshe is candid, self-deprecating, laugh-out-loud funny. At first an awkward newbie in Afghanistan, she grows into a wisecracking, seasoned reporter with grave concerns about US forces' ability to win hearts and minds in the region. In [_The Taliban Shuffle_](http://www.scribepublications.com.au/book/thetalibanshuffle), Barker offers an insider's account of the 'forgotten war' in Afghanistan and Pakistan, chronicling the years after America's initial routing of the Taliban. When Barker arrives in Kabul, foreign aid is at a record low, electricity is a pipe dream, and of the few remaining foreign troops, some aren't allowed out after dark. Meanwhile, in the vacuum left by the US and NATO, the Taliban is regrouping. Tickets are $5. Book through the Avid Reader website [here](http://www.avidreader.com.au/index.php?option=com_registrationpro&view=event&Itemid=2&did=225)
attributes.title: Kim Barker at Avid Reader Bookshop

attributes.content_markup:
Special Radio National live recording with Paul Barclay

Growing up in a strict Muslim community in south-east London, Alom Shaha learnt that religion was not to be questioned. Reciting the Qurâan without understanding what it meant was simply a part of life; so, too, was obeying the imam and enduring beatings when he failed to attend the local mosque. Shaha was more drawn to science and its power to illuminate. As a teen, he lived between two worlds: the home controlled by his authoritarian father, and a school alive with books and ideas.

In a charming blend of memoir, philosophy, and science, Shaha explores the questions about faith and the afterlife that we all ponder. Through a series of loose âlessonsâ, he tells his own compelling story, drawing on the theories of some of historyâs greatest thinkers and interrogating the fallacies that have impeded humanity for centuries. Shaha recounts how his education and formative experiences led him to question how to live without being tied to what his parents, priests, or teachers told him to believe, and offers insights so that others may do the same.

Shaha’s book, The Young Atheistâs Handbook, is a book for anyone who thinks about what they should believe and how they should live. Itâs for those who may need the facts and the ideas, as well as the courage, to break free from inherited beliefs. In this powerful narrative, Shaha shows that it is possible to live a compassionate, fulfilling, and meaningful life without God.

Tickets are $5. Book through the Avid Reader website here

attributes.content_markup:
Chris Womersley, author of Bereft and The Low Road will be appearing at the Bookworm Literary Festival in China.

Bereft is set in the years after WW I in an Australia ravaged by the Spanish flu epidemic. Accused of an unspeakable crime – the brutal murder of a beloved sister – Quinn Walker fled his home. Ten years on, he returns from the front to seek his revenge and lay the ghosts of his past to rest. Womersley discusses longing, justice and the stories we tell to heal the wounds of war.

About the Festival The Bookworm International Literary Festival is hosted across three of Chinaâs most vibrant locales: the political heart of China and its erstwhile imperial seat, Beijing, the romantic canal-driven and one hundred-gardened Suzhou, and the cultural hub of Sichuanâs sultry capital Chengdu.

Brought to you by the Australian Council.

65 RMB
attributes.content:
Chris Womersley, author of [*Bereft* ](http://scribepublications.com.au/books-authors/title/bereft/) and [*The Low Road*](http://scribepublications.com.au/books-authors/title/the-low-road/) will be appearing at the Bookworm Literary Festival in China.

Chris Womersley, author of Bereft and The Low Road will be appearing at the Bookworm Literary Festival in China on a panel discussion themed on ‘The Underbelly’.

Are drug-addicts, murderers and duplicitous gangsters misunderstood misfits with hearts of gold or low-life scum? Three writers â Paul French (UK), Yrsa SigurÃ°ardÃ³ttir (Iceland) and Chris Womersley (Australia) â delve into the underbelly to investigate those who live outside the law on the fringes of society. Join us to find out if there is a criminal code or if there really is no honour among thieves. Moderated by crime writer Catherine Sampson.

About the Festival The Bookworm International Literary Festival is hosted across three of Chinaâs most vibrant locales: the political heart of China and its erstwhile imperial seat, Beijing, the romantic canal-driven and one hundred-gardened Suzhou, and the cultural hub of Sichuanâs sultry capital Chengdu.

65 RMB

attributes.content_markup:
The middle class backyard is an iconic fixture in the Australian psyche. Half a century after the suburban sprawl colonised the urban bushland, many of us still relate to the backyard, and many of us still aspire to the ideal. But how does a writer find inspiration here? And is it the romance or the horror of suburbia that fires our authors?

Fiona McGregor, author of Indelible Ink, will be speaking about the tragicomic realities of suburban living on a panel with Judith Lucy and Patrick Holland. More details can be found here.
attributes.content:
*The middle class backyard is an iconic fixture in the Australian psyche. Half a century after the suburban sprawl colonised the urban bushland, many of us still relate to the backyard, and many of us still aspire to the ideal. But how does a writer find inspiration here? And is it the romance or the horror of suburbia that fires our authors?*
Fiona McGregor, author of[ *Indelible Ink*](http://scribepublications.com.au/books-authors/title/indelible-ink/), will be speaking about the tragicomic realities of suburban living on a panel with Judith Lucy and Patrick Holland. More details can be found [here.](http://wordstorm.org.au/)

attributes.content_markup: Glenn Carle says he would not use physical torture when interrogating a supposed top al Qaeda operative rendered to one of the CIAâs notorious black sites overseas. Carle, who later served as Deputy National Intelligence Officer for Transnational Threats (i.e., terrorism) â the US Intelligence Communityâs most senior position for terrorism analysis â is the only CIA officer to have spoken out, and written, about rendition, detention, interrogation, and torture. He talks to David Leser about his autobiography The Interrogator (heavily redacted by the CIA) and how he wrestled with what defined his real duty to his country. For full details of the session see here.
attributes.content: Glenn Carle says he would not use physical torture when interrogating a supposed top al Qaeda operative rendered to one of the CIAâs notorious black sites overseas. He talks to David Leser about his autobiography *The Interrogator* (heavily redacted by the CIA) and how he wrestled with what defined his real duty to his country. For full details of the session see [here](http://www.swf.org.au/component/option,com_events/Itemid,124/agid,2978/task,view_detail/).
attributes.title: Glenn Carle, Interview with the Interrogator - Sydney Writers' Festival

attributes.content_markup: How is it that our supposedly liberal democratic governments engage in torture? What does it say about our political culture that this is an acceptable way to fight terrorism? Or is it? Former CIA interrogator Glenn Carle is a strong critic of US government practice. He talks with Danielle Celermajer, who is heading up a major research project looking at the prevention of torture. For full session details see here.
attributes.content: How is it that our supposedly liberal democratic governments engage in torture? What does it say about our political culture that this is an acceptable way to fight terrorism? Or is it? Former CIA interrogator Glenn Carle is a strong critic of US government practice. He talks with Danielle Celermajer, who is heading up a major research project looking at the prevention of torture. For full session details see [here](http://www.swf.org.au/component/option,com_events/Itemid,124/agid,3234/task,view_detail/).
attributes.title: Glenn Carle, Preventing Torture - Sydney Writers' Festival

attributes.content_markup: âPrivacy is for paedos,â News of the World journo Paul McMullan famously told the Leveson Inquiry. Privacy is dead, said Google CEO Eric Schmidt. Through social media we voluntarily tell the world things we previously might not have told even our loved ones. Investigative journalists thrive on leaks and finding out what others donât want them to know. How far should the state go to prevent another 9/11? Is everything fair game? What is left of the private domain in the age of the Kardashians? And, as individuals, shouldnât we want to have things (however trivial) to hide? Former director general of MI5 Dame Stella Rimington, Ex CIA interrogator of Al Quaeda suspects Glenn Carle, independent investigative journalist Heather Brooke, and former High Court judge, the Hon Michael Kirby, tell journalist David Marr where we, as a society, should draw the line between public and private. For full session details see here.
attributes.content: âPrivacy is for paedos,â *News of the World* journo Paul McMullan famously told the Leveson Inquiry. Privacy is dead, said Google CEO Eric Schmidt. Through social media we voluntarily tell the world things we previously might not have told even our loved ones. Investigative journalists thrive on leaks and finding out what others donât want them to know. How far should the state go to prevent another 9/11? Is everything fair game? What is left of the private domain in the age of the Kardashians? And, as individuals, shouldnât we want to have things (however trivial) to hide? Former director general of MI5 Dame Stella Rimington, Ex CIA interrogator of Al Quaeda suspects Glenn Carle, independent investigative journalist Heather Brooke, and former High Court judge, the Hon Michael Kirby, tell journalist David Marr where we, as a society, should draw the line between public and private. For full session details see [here](http://www.swf.org.au/component/option,com_events/Itemid,124/agid,2981/task,view_detail/).
attributes.title: Glenn Carle, You Must Have Something to Hide - Sydney Writers' Festival

attributes.content_markup: Glenn Carle was a high-ranking interrogator for the CIA, expected to get information out of Al Quaeda suspects by whatever means. He refused and ultimately resigned. In his book The Interrogator he takes the reader on an ethical journey: What is duty? Can a public official â a national security official â challenge the established, moral code as defined by oneâs orders? For full details of the session see here.
attributes.content: Glenn Carle was a high-ranking interrogator for the CIA, expected to get information out of Al Quaeda suspects by whatever means. He refused and ultimately resigned. In his book *The Interrogator *he takes the reader on an ethical journey: What is duty? Can a public official â a national security official â challenge the established, moral code as defined by oneâs orders? For full details of the session see [here](http://www.swf.org.au/component/option,com_events/Itemid,124/agid,3237/task,view_detail/).
attributes.title: Glenn Carle, No More Nuremburg Defence - Sydney Writers' Festival

attributes.content_markup: Sometimes in our jobs we are called upon to do things that are distasteful, unacceptable, even unlawful. What do we do in such circumstances? Glenn Carle, a senior CIA operative, challenged the chain of command, all the way up to the president, when he was expected to torture an al Quaeda suspect. Peter Mitchell, employed by the Department of Immigration at the Villawood Detention Centre, had to tell stressed-out people their asylum claims had been denied. They talk to Simon Longstaff, Director, St James Ethics Centre, about individual responsibility versus organisational demands. For full session details see here.
attributes.content: Sometimes in our jobs we are called upon to do things that are distasteful, unacceptable, even unlawful. What do we do in such circumstances? attributes.title: Glenn Carle, You Want Me to What - Sydney Writers' Festival

attributes.title: Marc Lewis, Memoirs Of An Addicted Brain - Avid Reader

attributes.content_markup: There is recovery, or recovering, as people like to say, from addiction. Just ask Marc Lewis: as a young man he ingested whatever he could lay his hands on, and seemed to reach the point of no return. In his work, Lewis now looks at the brain processes underlying behavioural problems in children that often lead to drug and alcohol addiction. He has a blog on which a lot of recovering or ex-addicts are participating â a kind of online therapeutic community. Marc, and Lemon Anderson, tell ABC Radio Nationalâs Cassie McCullagh how they made it out. For full details of the session see here.
