attributes.title: Marc Lewis, The War on Drugs - Sydney Writers' Festival

attributes.content_markup: What happens to your brain when you feed it a diet of drugs, alcohol and other addictive substances? Nothing good, says Marc Lewis, a neuroscientist and professor, who has not only changed his ways and now helps young people fight addiction, but who has charted what these substances actually do to you. He talks to Lisa Pryor. For full session details see the SWF website.
attributes.content: What happens to your brain when you feed it a diet of drugs, alcohol and other addictive substances? He talks to Lisa Pryor. For full session details see [the SWF website](http://www.swf.org.au/component/option,com_events/Itemid,124/agid,3035/task,view_detail/).
attributes.title: Marc Lewis, Memoirs of an Addicted Brain - Sydney Writers' Festival

attributes.content_markup: Our brains can be capricious organs, ignoring our commands or punishing us for abuse, but they are probably the most fascinating thing we possess. And the advances in our understanding of the brain have profound ramifications beyond neuroscience, into virtually every aspect of everyday life. Barbara Arrowsmith Young trained hers and Marc Lewis tested his. They talk to Neil James. For full session details see here.

Meg Mundell, author of Black Glass, will be appearing at this year’s Continuum conference. She’ll be speaking at a session entitled ‘Melbourne’s Dark Side’:

Melbourne is often touted as one of the worldâs âMost Liveable Citiesâ, but donât be fooled: beneath the surface glitz and tourism spin lies a much darker version of the city, one that has provided rich inspiration for writers of horror, speculative fiction and sci-fi. Join our panelists for an exploratory and imaginative trip into Melbourneâs sinister side.

For more information about the conference, see here.
attributes.content:

attributes.content_markup:
India observers, devotees of immersion journalism and lovers of good writing agree: New Yorker staffer Katherine Booâs account of life in a Mumbai slum is the best book about India in decades. The New York Times says Behind the Beautiful Forevers reads âalmost like a novel: a true-life version of ‘Slumdog Millionaire’ without the Bollywood endingâ. Others have compared it to Dickens and Dante, Capote and Orwell.

Katherine won a Pulitzer Prize for her reporting at the Washington Post in 2000. She spent four years reporting from India for Behind the Beautiful Forevers, immersed in the daily life of Annawadi, the slum she brings to life in the book.

âVery little journalism is world changing,â she has said. âBut if change is to happen, it will be because people with power have a better sense of whatâs happening to people who have none.â

Katherine will be joined in conversation by the Wheeler Centreâs senior writer/editor Jo Case.
attributes.content:
India observers, devotees of immersion journalism and lovers of good writing agree: *New Yorker* staffer Katherine Booâs account of life in a Mumbai slum is the best book about India in decades. *The New York Times* says *Behind the Beautiful Forevers* reads âalmost like a novel: a true-life version of 'Slumdog Millionaire' without the Bollywood endingâ. Others have compared it to Dickens and Dante, Capote and Orwell.
Katherine won a Pulitzer Prize for her reporting at the *Washington Post* in 2000. She spent four years reporting from India for B*ehind the Beautiful Forevers*, immersed in the daily life of Annawadi, the slum she brings to life in the book.
âVery little journalism is world changing,â she has said. âBut if change is to happen, it will be because people with power have a better sense of whatâs happening to people who have none.â
Katherine will be joined in conversation by the Wheeler Centreâs senior writer/editor Jo Case.
attributes.title: Katherine Boo at The Wheeler Centre

FREE

With the recent restructuring of Fairfax and News Ltd, just when will be D-Day for the printing press? What is quality journalism and will it survive? Susan Johnson, Jeff Sparrow and John Lanchester discuss with Stephen Romei.

Price: $25. Book here.
attributes.content:
With the recent restructuring of Fairfax and News Ltd, just when will be D-Day for the printing press? What is quality journalism and will it survive? Susan Johnson, [Jeff Sparrow](http://scribepublications.com.au/books-authors/author/jeff-sparrow/) and John Lanchester discuss with Stephen Romei.
Price: $25. Book [here.](http://www.brisbanewritersfestival.com.au/default.asp?PageID=254&EventID=278)
attributes.title: Jeff Sparrow at the Brisbane Writers Festival: Paywalls: Improving the Quality of Journalism

attributes.content_markup:
Debates about pornography and censorship are usually pitched as contests between a libertarian left and a puritanical right. But does that schema adequately describe the arguments taking place today? What happens to censorship and sexuality in a world of radical market freedom? Jeff Sparrow will be delivering a one-off talk for the Melbourne Free University based on his new book, Money Shot: a journey into censorship and porn..

Melbourne Free University events are free and open to the public.
attributes.content:

The Friends of Emerald Hill Library invite you to meet acclaimed Australian author Jacinta Halloran.

Jacinta will be talking about her new novel Pilgrimage, a powerful meditation on how our personal histories haunt us, and an affirmation of the hope and sustenance that may be found in our imperfect families.

This is a free event, with no bookings necessary.

All enquiries to Michael from the Friends of Emerald Hill Library, ph: 0417556143
attributes.content:

attributes.content_markup:
Breaking the Silence is an internationally lauded Israeli NGO established in 2004 by Israel Defense Forces veterans to document the testimonies of soldiers who have served in the Occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

Avner Gvaryahu, a former soldier who now works for Breaking the Silence, will be in conversation with Raimond Gaita about the NGO’s work, the many ethical and political questions that arise from it, and the new book Our Harsh Logic: Israeli soldiers' testimonies from the Occupied Territories, 2000-2010.

Free, but please book on 9819 1917

attributes.content_markup:
Ned Kelly Award-nominated author Robert Gott joins us to discuss his most recent work, The Holiday Murders. Gott has established himself as a cartoonist with his Naked Man series and as a crime writer. His books include Good Murder, A Thing of Blood and Amongst the Dead. The Holiday Murders, a compelling page-turner of a novel set in 1943, explores a little-known and sometimes violent corner of Australian history, and finds oddly modern echoes in its paranoia, xenophobia, and ugly fervour. Robert will be in conversation with Angela Savage, author of Behind the Night Bazaar and winner of the Scarlet Stiletto Award

Cost: $110.00 for couples; $70.00 for singles. Includes a signed copy of The Holiday Murders, a welcome drink and a delectable two-course candlelit dinner. Places are limited. Red stilettos/berets can vie for a door prize. Prepaid early bookings are essential: (03) 9439 8700 or elthambookshop@bigpond.com
attributes.content:
Ned Kelly Award-nominated author Robert Gott joins us to discuss his most recent work, [*The Holiday Murders*](http://scribepublications.com.au/books-authors/title/the-holiday-murders/). Gott has established himself as a cartoonist with his Naked Man series and as a crime writer. His books include *Good Murder, A Thing of Blood* and *Amongst the Dead*. *The Holiday Murders*, a compelling page-turner of a novel set in 1943, explores a little-known and sometimes violent corner of Australian history, and finds oddly modern echoes in its paranoia, xenophobia, and ugly fervour. Robert will be in conversation with Angela Savage, author of *Behind the Night Bazaar* and winner of the Scarlet Stiletto Award
Cost: $110.00 for couples; $70.00 for singles. Includes a signed copy of *The Holiday Murders*, a welcome drink and a delectable two-course candlelit dinner. Places are limited. Red stilettos/berets can vie for a door prize. Prepaid early bookings are essential: (03) 9439 8700 or elthambookshop@bigpond.com
attributes.title: A Literary Dinner with Robert Gott

attributes.content_markup: Hear Jill talk about her memoir High Sobriety: My year without booze with ABC Radio National’s Paul Barclay. $7.50, Bookings: 07 3846 3422
attributes.content: Hear Jill talk about her memoir [High Sobriety: My year without booze](http://scribepublications.com.au/books-authors/title/high-sobriety/) with ABC Radio National's Paul Barclay. $7.50, Bookings: 07 3846 3422
attributes.title: Jill Stark in conversation with Paul Barclay

attributes.content_markup: Jill Stark, a Sunday Age writer specialising in alcohol and public health issues, came to write her first book, High Sobriety, after one big night too many. On January 1 2011, she woke up with the hangover of all hangovers and decided it was time for a well overdue break from the booze. âThe irony was that binge drinking had been my job â for more than five years, Iâd written about the health and social consequences of Australiaâs alcohol consumption. At the weekends, I wrote myself off.â At The Wheeler Centre Hear her discuss the clash of those two worlds â and Australiaâs conflicted relationship with alcohol consumption.
attributes.content: Jill Stark, a Sunday Age writer specialising in alcohol and public health issues, came to write her first book, [High Sobriety](http://scribepublications.com.au/books-authors/title/high-sobriety/), after one big night too many. On January 1 2011, she woke up with the hangover of all hangovers and decided it was time for a well overdue break from the booze. âThe irony was that binge drinking had been my job â for more than five years, Iâd written about the health and social consequences of Australiaâs alcohol consumption. At the weekends, I wrote myself off.â At [The Wheeler Centre](http://wheelercentre.com/calendar/event/jill-stark-high-sobriety-my-year-without-booze/) Hear her discuss the clash of those two worlds â and Australiaâs conflicted relationship with alcohol consumption.
attributes.title: Lunchbox / Soapbox: Jill Stark: High Sobriety: My Year Without Booze

attributes.content_markup: Jill Stark is a Sunday Age writer specialising in public health issues who woke up on New Year’s Day 2011 with a hangover to beat all hangovers and decided that it was time to take a break from drinking. The result of this year of abstinence is High Sobriety a sobering and very personal look at Australia’s sometimes troubled relationship with alcohol consumption. At Belmont Library
attributes.content: Jill Stark is a Sunday Age writer specialising in public health issues who woke up on New Year's Day 2011 with a hangover to beat all hangovers and decided that it was time to take a break from drinking. The result of this year of abstinence is [High Sobriety](http://scribepublications.com.au/books-authors/title/high-sobriety/) a sobering and very personal look at Australia's sometimes troubled relationship with alcohol consumption. At [Belmont Library](http://www.grlc.vic.gov.au/event/author-talk-jill-stark-high-sobriety)
attributes.title: Author Talk: Jill Stark, 'High Sobriety'

attributes.content_markup:
The Black Saturday bushfires killed 173 people â ten of those people died in Steels Creek, a small community on Melbourneâs fringe. Prize-winning historian Peter Stanley tells the dramatic stories of this small town on that one terrifying evening. But Black Saturday at Steels Creek also tells the tale of a community and how, over the weeks and years that followed, they lived with the aftermath of the fire.

Book online here.
attributes.content:
The Black Saturday bushfires killed 173 people â ten of those people died in Steels Creek, a small community on Melbourneâs fringe. Prize-winning historian Peter Stanley tells the dramatic stories of this small town on that one terrifying evening. But [*Black Saturday at Steels Creek*](http://scribepublications.com.au/books-authors/title/black-saturday-at-steels-creek/) also tells the tale of a community and how, over the weeks and years that followed, they lived with the aftermath of the fire.
Book online [here](http://www.geelonglibraries.vic.gov.au/event/author-talk-peter-stanley-black-saturday-steels-creek).
attributes.title: Peter Stanley at Geelong Library

attributes.content_markup:
New media technologies are rapidly transforming not just the world of work but the nature of politics, journalism, education and our everyday social lives. Today Google is indispensable, Facebook has over 2 billion subscribers, Twitter generates 340 million Tweets every day and has increasing power as a broadcast platform with political clout. Mobile technology is replacing older forms of communication and new developments loom on the horizon.

For more information and bookings, see here.

Geust speakers include Margaret Simons, Director of the Centre for Advanced Journalism, University of Melbourne and the author of numerous books including Journalism at the Crossroads, and Greg Jericho, author of The Rise of The Fifth Estate.
attributes.content:
New media technologies are rapidly transforming not just the world of work but the nature of politics, journalism, education and our everyday social lives. Today Google is indispensable, Facebook has over 2 billion subscribers, Twitter generates 340 million Tweets every day and has increasing power as a broadcast platform with political clout. Mobile technology is replacing older forms of communication and new developments loom on the horizon.
For more information and bookings, see [here](http://www.unicol.unimelb.edu.au/alumni-events/1861/).
Geust speakers include Margaret Simons, Director of the Centre for Advanced Journalism, University of Melbourne and the author of numerous books including [*Journalism at the Crossroads*](http://scribepublications.com.au/books-authors/title/journalism-at-the-crossroads/), and Greg Jericho, author of [*The Rise of The Fifth Estate*](http://scribepublications.com.au/books-authors/title/the-rise-of-the-fifth-estate/).
attributes.title: Meg Simons and Greg Jericho at the University of Melbourne's Alumni Forum on Social Media and Society

To celebrate the launch of Dirt Files, the Australian National University in conjunction with The Canberra Times is hosting an exhibition of cartoons from the anthology and a panel discussion between editor Russ Radliffe and contributing cartoonists Geoff Pryor and David Pope. Together they will be reviewing ten years in Australian politics through the cartoons which have captured the decade, and reflecting on the figures and issues which have defined an era as we move into election season.

This is a free event. Book online here.
attributes.content:
To celebrate the launch of [*Dirt Files*](http://scribepublications.com.au/books-authors/title/dirt-files/), the Australian National University in conjunction with *The Canberra Times* is hosting an exhibition of cartoons from the anthology and a panel discussion between editor Russ Radliffe and contributing cartoonists Geoff Pryor and David Pope. Together they will be reviewing ten years in Australian politics through the cartoons which have captured the decade, and reflecting on the figures and issues which have defined an era as we move into election season.
This is a free event. Book online [here](http://dirtfiles.eventbrite.com/).
attributes.title: The Launch of Dirt Files

attributes.content_markup:
Author talk: Jill Stark was a binge-drinking health reporter for the Sunday Age. During the week she wrote about the health and social consequences of Australiaâs booze-soaked culture. On the weekends, sheâd write herself off. After one too many hangovers, she decided on a period of abstinence. Hear Jill talk about her memoir, High Sobriety, that charts her tumultuous year on the wagon, as well as discussing Australiaâs obsession with alcohol.

FREE
attributes.content:
Author talk: Jill Stark was a binge-drinking health reporter for the *Sunday Age*. During the week she wrote about the health and social consequences of Australiaâs booze-soaked culture. On the weekends, sheâd write herself off. After one too many hangovers, she decided on a period of abstinence. Hear Jill talk about her memoir, [High Sobriety](http://scribepublications.com.au/books-authors/title/high-sobriety/), that charts her tumultuous year on the wagon, as well as discussing Australiaâs obsession with alcohol.
[FREE](http://highsobriety-eorg.eventbrite.com.au/)
attributes.title: High sobriety: my year without booze

attributes.content_markup:
Cairo is the latest release by multi-award winning author Chris Wormersley (The Low Road and Bereft) and is the story of seventeen-year-old Tom Button. Moving to the city to study, Tom is swept up in a bohemian world of parties and gallery openings. Soon, however, he is caught up in more sinister events involving deception and betrayal, and one of the greatest unsolved art heists of the twentieth century: the infamous theft of Picassoâs Weeping Woman.

FREE book here
attributes.content:
[Cairo](http://scribepublications.com.au/books-authors/title/cairo/) is the latest release by multi-award winning author Chris Wormersley (*The Low Road* and *Bereft*) and is the story of seventeen-year-old Tom Button. Moving to the city to study, Tom is swept up in a bohemian world of parties and gallery openings. Soon, however, he is caught up in more sinister events involving deception and betrayal, and one of the greatest unsolved art heists of the twentieth century: the infamous theft of Picassoâs Weeping Woman.

attributes.content_markup:
Join authors Tim Dunlop and Rachel Buchanan, talking to media guru Lynne Haultain, for a provocative panel discussion on the death of newspapers.

Tim Dunlop was a pioneer of political blogging in Australia, and is the author of ‘The New Front Page: New Media and the Rise of the Audience'.

Rachel Buchanan has worked as a newspaper reporter, feature writer, columnist and subeditor for newspapers including The Age, and is the author of ‘Stop Press: the Last Days of Newspapers’.
attributes.content:
Join authors Tim Dunlop and Rachel Buchanan, talking to media guru Lynne Haultain, for a provocative panel discussion on the death of newspapers.
Tim Dunlop was a pioneer of political blogging in Australia, and is the author of '[The New Front Page: New Media and the Rise of the Audience'](http://scribepublications.com.au/books-authors/title/the-new-front-page/).
Rachel Buchanan has worked as a newspaper reporter, feature writer, columnist and subeditor for newspapers including The Age, and is the author of ['Stop Press: the Last Days of Newspapers'](http://scribepublications.com.au/books-authors/title/stop-press/).
attributes.title: Media Chronicles

attributes.content_markup:
Based on the annual bestseller Best Australian Political Cartoons 2013 edited by Russ Radcliffe.

2013 is a year many people would prefer to forget: three prime ministers, a brutal leadership battle driven by thwarted ambition and desire for revenge, and a comically negative opposition leader watching from the sidelines eager to pick up the spoils.

But for political cartoonists, bloated egos, poisonous rivalries and general chaos are gifts not to be wasted.

This exhibition, filled with sparkling wit and penetrating insight, celebrates some of Australiaâs finest political cartoons from this period â small but unforgettable âsuppositories of wisdomâ.

Please join Russ Radcliffe at Antipodes for a free talk on political cartooning on:

Saturday 5 April, 2.00 pm AND Saturday 18 April, 2.00 pm

Entry is free
attributes.content:
**Based on the annual bestseller *[Best Australian Political Cartoons 2013](http://scribepublications.com.au/books-authors/title/best-australian-political-cartoons-2013/)* edited by Russ Radcliffe.**
2013 is a year many people would prefer to forget: three prime ministers, a brutal leadership battle driven by thwarted ambition and desire for revenge, and a comically negative opposition leader watching from the sidelines eager to pick up the spoils.
But for political cartoonists, bloated egos, poisonous rivalries and general chaos are gifts not to be wasted.
This exhibition, filled with sparkling wit and penetrating insight, celebrates some of Australiaâs finest political cartoons from this period â small but unforgettable âsuppositories of wisdomâ.
Please join Russ Radcliffe at Antipodes for a **free talk** on political cartooning on:
**Saturday 5 April, 2.00 pm AND Saturday 18 April, 2.00 pm**
Entry is free
attributes.title: Suppositories of Wisdom: an exhibition of the best political cartoons of 2013 â 5 April to 3 May 2014

attributes.content_markup: Sydeny Writers Festival: For the Festivalâs first session of the day, join Sherrill Nixon, state editor at The Sydney Morning Herald, SMH journalists and SWF special guest Richard King author of On Offence, to hear their take on whatâs making news headlines today and the changing nature of journalism. Supported by The Sydney Morning Herald.
attributes.content: [Sydeny Writers Festival: ](http://www.swf.org.au/component/option,com_events/Itemid,124/agid,3847/task,view_detail/)For the Festivalâs first session of the day, join Sherrill Nixon, state editor at The Sydney Morning Herald, SMH journalists and SWF special guest Richard King author of [On Offence](http://scribepublications.com.au/books-authors/title/on-offence/), to hear their take on whatâs making news headlines today and the changing nature of journalism. Supported by The Sydney Morning Herald.
attributes.title: Coffee and Papers with The Sydney Morning Herald and Richard King

attributes.content_markup: Sydney Writers Festival: In recent decades, taking offence has become a form of political currency. Indignation is whipped up and weaponised and hurt feelings paraded like union banners. Richard King argues that this obsessive emphasis on âsensitivityâ eats away at genuine civility; that the claim to find something hurtful or offensive should be the beginning of the debate, not the end of it; and that freedom of speech is meaningless unless it includes the freedom to offend.
attributes.content: [Sydney Writers Festival: ](http://www.swf.org.au/component/option,com_events/Itemid,124/agid,4041/task,view_detail/) In recent decades, taking offence has become a form of political currency. Indignation is whipped up and weaponised and hurt feelings paraded like union banners. [Richard King](http://scribepublications.com.au/books-authors/title/on-offence/) argues that this obsessive emphasis on âsensitivityâ eats away at genuine civility; that the claim to find something hurtful or offensive should be the beginning of the debate, not the end of it; and that freedom of speech is meaningless unless it includes the freedom to offend.
attributes.title: Curiosity Lecture Series: On Offence

attributes.content: Ari Shavit will speak on *[My Promised Land](http://scribepublications.com.au/books-authors/title/my-promised-land/)* on Wednesday 21 May, 7.30pm at Monash Caulfield Campus (H1.16 Ground Floor, H Building). No cost. No Prior bookings. artsonline.monash.edu.au/acjc
attributes.title: Ari Shavit talk at Monash Caulfield

attributes.content_markup: Sydney Writers' Festival: Taking and giving offence is a new form of political currency, at times whipping up indignation in place of rational debate. When being offended ends rather than starts an argument, what are the repercussions for public discourse? Hear Michael Leunig, whose playful provocations help âcounter the silence of conservatismâ, Richard King (On OffenceLink Text) on the importance of argument in a civil society, Human Rights Commissioner Tim Wilson on why offence is necessary to move society forward and Neil James on how rediscovering rhetoric can help us distinguish between insult and argument. They speak to Peter FitzSimons.
attributes.content: [Sydney Writers' Festival](http://www.swf.org.au/component/option,com_events/Itemid,124/agid,4082/task,view_detail/): Taking and giving offence is a new form of political currency, at times whipping up indignation in place of rational debate. When being offended ends rather than starts an argument, what are the repercussions for public discourse? Hear Michael Leunig, whose playful provocations help âcounter the silence of conservatismâ, Richard King (*On Offence*[Link Text](http://scribepublications.com.au/books-authors/title/on-offence/)) on the importance of argument in a civil society, Human Rights Commissioner Tim Wilson on why offence is necessary to move society forward and Neil James on how rediscovering rhetoric can help us distinguish between insult and argument. They speak to Peter FitzSimons.
attributes.title: The Art of Indignation

attributes.content_markup: Sydney Writers' Festival The PersianâJewish relationship goes back thousands of years and has been marked by both tolerance and tyranny. Hear from IranianâAmerican writer and scholar of religions Reza Aslan (Zealot) and Ari Shavit whose My Promised Land examines the complexities of the Israeli condition. They will talk about their personal relationship to their homelands and look at the larger political dynamic between these two countries. Chair: ABC Radioâs Eleanor Hall.
attributes.content: [Sydney Writers' Festival](http://www.swf.org.au/component/option,com_events/Itemid,124/agid,3926/task,view_detail/) The PersianâJewish relationship goes back thousands of years and has been marked by both tolerance and tyranny. Hear from IranianâAmerican writer and scholar of religions Reza Aslan (Zealot) and Ari Shavit whose *[My Promised Land](http://scribepublications.com.au/books-authors/title/my-promised-land/)* examines the complexities of the Israeli condition. They will talk about their personal relationship to their homelands and look at the larger political dynamic between these two countries. Chair: ABC Radioâs Eleanor Hall.
attributes.title: An Iranian talking to an Israeli: Reza Aslan with Ari Shavit

attributes.content_markup: Sydney Writers' Festival Facing unprecedented internal and external pressures, Israel is at a moment of existential crisis. My Promised Land: The Triumph and Tragedy of Israel tells the story of Israel as it has never been told before, and asks difficult but important questions: Why and how did Israel come to be? Can Israel survive? Ari Shavitâs unique writing, which challenges the dogmas of both the right and left, has made him one of the leading political thinkers of the Jewish state.
attributes.content: [Sydney Writers' Festival](http://www.swf.org.au/component/option,com_events/Itemid,124/agid,3827/task,view_detail/) Facing unprecedented internal and external pressures, Israel is at a moment of existential crisis. *[My Promised Land: The Triumph and Tragedy of Israel](http://scribepublications.com.au/books-authors/title/my-promised-land/)* tells the story of Israel as it has never been told before, and asks difficult but important questions: Why and how did Israel come to be? Can Israel survive? Ari Shavitâs unique writing, which challenges the dogmas of both the right and left, has made him one of the leading political thinkers of the Jewish state.
attributes.title: Ari Shavit: My Promised Land

attributes.content_markup: Sydney Writers' Festival: Buy a cupcake and sit down for a beautiful morning tea with your favourite authors and illustrators. When else will you ever get to ask Inkheart and Ghost Hunters author Cornelia Funke as many questions as you can fit in between mouthfuls of cake? Or get to tell Jacqueline Harvey that you are the NUMBER ONE Alice-Miranda fan in the world? Donât miss out on this once-in-a-lifetime chance to sit down with some of the best authors and illustrators in the whole world including Ursula Dubosarsky, Jane Godwin, Gus Gordon, Eliza Sarlos, Deborah Kelly and more. Who knows, maybe they will even sign a book or two … Your friends will be so jealous! (All ages)

attributes.content_markup: Kate Richards in conversation with Jacinta Halloran: Kate Richards is an award-winning writer of narrative non-fiction, fiction and poetry. Her memoir, Madness, was published by Penguin Books in February 2013. It’s the true story of a journey from chaos to balance, and limbo to meaning. Kate has a medical degree and a diploma of arts and is an advocate for living well with disability and long-term illness. Jacinta’s most recent novel is Pilgrimage.
attributes.content: [Kate Richards in conversation with Jacinta Halloran:](http://library.portphillip.vic.gov.au/Whats_on/Library_events/In_conversation_with_Kate_Richards) Kate Richards is an award-winning writer of narrative non-fiction, fiction and poetry. Her memoir, Madness, was published by Penguin Books in February 2013. It's the true story of a journey from chaos to balance, and limbo to meaning. Kate has a medical degree and a diploma of arts and is an advocate for living well with disability and long-term illness. [Jacinta's most recent novel is Pilgrimage.](http://scribepublications.com.au/books-authors/author/jacinta-halloran/)
attributes.title: In conversation with Kate Richards

Please join us to celebrate the launch of Why Aren’t We Dead Yet?: the survivor’s guide to the immune system by Idan Ben-Barak. In this lively and accessible book, Idan explores the immune system and what keeps it running, how we fight off viruses and infections, and the role of antibiotics and vaccines.

The launch will be held on Thursday 7 August from 6.30pm to 8pm at Embiggen Books, 197â203 Little Lonsdale Street, Melbourne. Send RSVPs to kate@scribepub.com.au.
attributes.content:

In this lively and accessible book, Idan explores the immune system and what keeps it running, how we fight off viruses and infections, and the role of antibiotics and vaccines.

Mark Mulholland, author of A Mad and Wonderful Thing, is appearing at the following events at this year’s Brisbane Writers Festival:

‘Stranger than Truth’ on Friday 5 September from 2â3pm When truth informs fiction why is it necessary to fictionalise it? Mark Mulholland and Brigid Delaney share the story behind the story of their controversial debut novels.

‘A Mad and Wonderful Thing’ on Saturday 6 September from 11:30amâ12:30pm Sometimes good people do bad things. Meet Johnny Donnelly, booklover and IRA sniper, in Mark Mulhollandâs charming and redemptive debut novel, A Mad and Wonderful Thing, inspired in part by Markâs own brother, jailed as an IRA terrorist. Join him in conversation with Laura Kroetsch.

‘Reading’ on Sunday 7 September from 12:15â12:45pm Irish writer Mark Mulholland reads from his novel A Mad and Wonderful Thing.

To buy tickets, visit the Brisbane Writers Festival website.

David Roland, author of How I Rescued My Brain, is appearing at the following events at this year’s Brisbane Writers Festival:

‘What is a Mind?’ on Friday 5 September from 3.30pm to 4.30pm What is consciousness? Is the mind merely a function of our biology or something more? Antony Funnell explores the intangible and mysterious with Damon Young, Kate Richards, Sean Williams and David Roland.

‘How I Rescued My Brain on Saturday 6 September from 2:30â3:30PM After psychologist David Roland suffered a stroke which resulted in brain injury, he faced two choices: give up, or get his brain working again. How I Rescued My Brain is the story of Davidâs remarkable cognitive recovery.

To buy tickets, visit the Brisbane Writers Festival website.

attributes.content_markup:
Nonfiction: what even is it?

Three prominent nonfiction writers come together to discuss their craft and what constitutes the genre of nonfiction â including how much room for creativity there might be within the scope of memoir and that contested category, creative nonfiction.

Melbourne writer Briohny Doyle and Sydney author Oliver Mol were the joint winners of the inaugural Scribe Nonfiction Prize, with young ACT genius Rosanna Stevens highly commended. They’ll join chair Lefa Singleton Norton to discuss and debate the nuances of nonfiction, including the ethics of writing about others' lives; when the truth can be bent in favour of narrative, and when it crosses the line to become fiction; and whether an author should show more fidelity to the historical record or to their readers' desires. They’ll explore the question: is reality stranger than fiction?

The event from Express Media will also feature the announcement of the shortlist for the 2014 Scribe Nonfiction Prize.

Bending the Truth? will be held at the Wheeler Centre on Friday 7 November at 7.30pm.
attributes.content:
Nonfiction: what even is it?
Three prominent nonfiction writers come together to discuss their craft and what constitutes the genre of nonfiction â including how much room for creativity there might be within the scope of memoir and that contested category, creative nonfiction.
Melbourne writer Briohny Doyle and Sydney author Oliver Mol were the joint winners of the inaugural Scribe Nonfiction Prize, with young ACT genius Rosanna Stevens highly commended. They'll join chair Lefa Singleton Norton to discuss and debate the nuances of nonfiction, including the ethics of writing about others' lives; when the truth can be bent in favour of narrative, and when it crosses the line to become fiction; and whether an author should show more fidelity to the historical record or to their readers' desires. They'll explore the question: is reality stranger than fiction?
The event from [Express Media](http://www.expressmedia.org.au/) will also feature the announcement of the shortlist for the 2014 Scribe Nonfiction Prize.
[Bending the Truth?](https://www.facebook.com/events/1486594514926059/) will be held at the Wheeler Centre on Friday 7 November at 7.30pm.
attributes.title: Bending the Truth?
